{"uri": "2024-05-373742431", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-30", "time": "20:51:51", "dateTime": "2024-05-30T20:51:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T20:41:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/news/world/biden-ukraine-permission-hit-russia-us-weapons-3083879", "title": "Biden gives Ukraine go-ahead to hit Russia with US weapons", "body": "The decision marks a major shift in the war, after the US initially said the move would escalate the conflict by more directly involving the US\n\nPresident Biden has quietly given Ukraine permission to strike Russian territory with US weapons in specific areas, according to a report.\n\nTwo United States officials and two other people familiar with the matter said Ukraine would be permitted to use US-supplied weapons in the north-eastern Kharkiv region, where Russia launched a new offensive this month.\n\n\"The President recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use US weapons for counter-fire purposes in Kharkiv so Ukraine can hit back at Russian forces hitting them or preparing to hit them,\" a US official told Politico, adding that the policy of allowing long-range strikes inside Russia had \"not changed\".\n\nThe move marks a major policy reversal after other countries including the Lord Cameron, the British Foreign Secretary, said that Ukraine had permission to use their weapons against Russian targets.\n\nIt means Kyiv can use American weapons to shoot down incoming Russian missiles and bombers, and at Russian forces massing over the border\n\nThe US official added that Ukraine had requested the policy change only after Russia launched its offensive on Kharkiv this month.\n\nA second official said the decision was made to give Ukraine \"flexibility\" to defend itself from attacks on the border.\n\nHowever, Ukraine will not be allowed to use long-range missiles, such as the Army Tactical Missile System (ATACMS), to hit military targets deep inside Russia, or to strike civilian targets.\n\nPresident Volodymyr Zelensky and other senior Ukrainian officials have complained that Russia is launching attacks from within its territory using assets that Ukrainian forces are unable to target.\n\nThe Biden administration has been reulctant to greenlight use of American weapons against Russia, over fears that it could escalate the war, with Russia recently escalating its threats against Western governments.", "source": {"uri": "inews.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "inews.co.uk"}, "authors": [{"uri": "https://wp.inews.co.uk/wp-content/uploads/2024/05/SEI_206685586.jpg?w=1200&h=675&crop=1", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9612325", "eventUri": "eng-9612325", "location": null, {"uri": "2024-05-373936468", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "03:08:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T03:08:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T03:06:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.wmur.com/article/biden-partially-lifts-ban-on-ukraine-using-us-arms-strikes-russia/60952725", "title": "Biden partially lifts ban on Ukraine using US arms in strikes on Russian territory", "body": "President Joe Biden has given Ukraine the go-ahead to use American weaponry to strike inside Russia for the limited purpose of defending Kharkiv, according to three U.S. officials familiar with the matter.The officials, who requested anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, underscored that the U.S. policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.Biden's directive allows for U.S.-supplied weapons to be used for \"counterfire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" one official said.The move comes as Ukrainian officials have stepped up calls on the U.S. administration to allow their forces to defend themselves against attacks originating from Russian territory. Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city, is just 20 kilometers (12 miles) from the Russian border.Biden's decision was first reported by Politico.Ukrainian officials, most notably Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, have been increasingly vocal in arguing that the restriction was putting Ukrainian forces in an untenable situation as Russia intensified attacks around the northeast Kharkiv region.The advances came with Russia exploiting a lengthy delay in replenishment of U.S. military aid and as Western Europe's inadequate military production has slowed crucial deliveries to the battlefield for Ukraine.During Secretary of State Antony Blinken's visit to Kyiv two weeks ago, Zelenskyy made his case for using American weapons to strike back at positions in Russia that were launching attacks into north and northeast Ukraine.Blinken was convinced and brought that message back to Washington, but it was ultimately Biden's decision to make, according to three U.S. officials who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss internal administration deliberations.Since the start of the Russian invasion in February 2022, Biden has been steadfast in his opposition to Ukraine's offensive use of American-made weaponry, concerned that the action could be seen as provocative and lead to Moscow widening the war.Blinken said in Moldova on Wednesday that U.S. policy on how Ukraine deploys American weapons is constantly evolving, hinting that Washington may alter its unwritten prohibition on Ukraine's use of them for attacks on Russian territory. On Thursday, Blinken joined NATO foreign ministers for a meeting in Prague, where during a tour of a Czech military base he saw armored vehicles that are being sent to Kyiv.Although U.S. officials insist there is no formal arms ban, they have long made clear that they believe the use of American weapons to attack targets inside Russia could provoke an escalatory response from Moscow, something that Russian President Vladimir Putin has promised.That position, Blinken noted, was a \"hallmark\" of the Biden administration's stance on Ukraine to \"adapt and adjust\" as needed.\"As the conditions have changed, as the battlefield has changed, as what Russia does has changed in terms of how it's pursuing its aggression, escalation, we've adapted and adjusted, too, and I'm confident we'll continue to do that,\" Blinken said at a news conference in Moldova.\"We're always listening, we're always learning, and we're always making determinations about what's necessary to make sure that Ukraine can effectively continue to defend itself, and we'll continue to do that,\" he said.Calls for a change in policy have been mounting.Earlier this week, French President Emmanuel Macron and NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said that Western countries should not object if Ukraine needs to strike inside Russia to defend itself. Stoltenberg reaffirmed that position on Thursday.\"I believe that time has come to (re)consider some of these restrictions to enable the Ukrainians to really defend themselves,\" he said. \"We need to remember what it is. This is a war of aggression launched by choice by Moscow against Ukraine.\"The right to self-defense, he said, \" includes also striking legitimate military targets outside Ukraine.\"Czech Foreign Minister Jan Lipavsky said at a NATO-related event Thursday in Prague that Ukraine needs resources to counter Russia's relentless assault.\"Ukraine cannot fight against Russia with one hand tied behind its back,\" he said. \"Ukraine must be able to fight against Russia's barbaric invasion even on Russian territory. Political resolve must be backed by credible capabilities.\"Norway's foreign minister, Espen Barth Eide, told Norwegian broadcaster NRK that his country believes Ukraine \"has a crystal-clear right under international law to attack Russia inside Russia as part of the defense of its territory.\"Biden's decision comes as he's set to travel to France early next month to attend D-Day 80th anniversary commemorations in Normandy, a watershed moment in changing the course of World War II. Zelenskyy is among dozens of world leaders expected to attend the D-Day commemorations.___Lee reported from Prague. Associated Press writers Karel Janicek in Prague and Ellen Knickmeyer contributed to this report.\n\nPresident Joe Biden has given Ukraine the go-ahead to use American weaponry to strike inside Russia for the limited purpose of defending Kharkiv, according to three U.S. officials familiar with the matter.\n\nThe officials, who requested anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, underscored that the U.S. policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.\n\nBiden's directive allows for U.S.-supplied weapons to be used for \"counterfire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" one official said.\n\nThe move comes as Ukrainian officials have stepped up calls on the U.S. administration to allow their forces to defend themselves against attacks originating from Russian territory. Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city, is just 20 kilometers (12 miles) from the Russian border.\n\nBiden's decision was first reported by Politico.\n\nUkrainian officials, most notably Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, have been increasingly vocal in arguing that the restriction was putting Ukrainian forces in an untenable situation as Russia intensified attacks around the northeast Kharkiv region.\n\nThe advances came with Russia exploiting a lengthy delay in replenishment of U.S. military aid and as Western Europe's inadequate military production has slowed crucial deliveries to the battlefield for Ukraine.\n\nDuring Secretary of State Antony Blinken's visit to Kyiv two weeks ago, Zelenskyy made his case for using American weapons to strike back at positions in Russia that were launching attacks into north and northeast Ukraine.\n\nBlinken was convinced and brought that message back to Washington, but it was ultimately Biden's decision to make, according to three U.S. officials who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss internal administration deliberations.\n\nSince the start of the Russian invasion in February 2022, Biden has been steadfast in his opposition to Ukraine's offensive use of American-made weaponry, concerned that the action could be seen as provocative and lead to Moscow widening the war.\n\nBlinken said in Moldova on Wednesday that U.S. policy on how Ukraine deploys American weapons is constantly evolving, hinting that Washington may alter its unwritten prohibition on Ukraine's use of them for attacks on Russian territory. On Thursday, Blinken joined NATO foreign ministers for a meeting in Prague, where during a tour of a Czech military base he saw armored vehicles that are being sent to Kyiv.\n\nAlthough U.S. officials insist there is no formal arms ban, they have long made clear that they believe the use of American weapons to attack targets inside Russia could provoke an escalatory response from Moscow, something that Russian President Vladimir Putin has promised.\n\nThat position, Blinken noted, was a \"hallmark\" of the Biden administration's stance on Ukraine to \"adapt and adjust\" as needed.\n\n\"As the conditions have changed, as the battlefield has changed, as what Russia does has changed in terms of how it's pursuing its aggression, escalation, we've adapted and adjusted, too, and I'm confident we'll continue to do that,\" Blinken said at a news conference in Moldova.\n\n\"We're always listening, we're always learning, and we're always making determinations about what's necessary to make sure that Ukraine can effectively continue to defend itself, and we'll continue to do that,\" he said.\n\nCalls for a change in policy have been mounting.\n\nEarlier this week, French President Emmanuel Macron and NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said that Western countries should not object if Ukraine needs to strike inside Russia to defend itself. Stoltenberg reaffirmed that position on Thursday.\n\n\"I believe that time has come to (re)consider some of these restrictions to enable the Ukrainians to really defend themselves,\" he said. \"We need to remember what it is. This is a war of aggression launched by choice by Moscow against Ukraine.\"\n\nThe right to self-defense, he said, \" includes also striking legitimate military targets outside Ukraine.\"\n\nCzech Foreign Minister Jan Lipavsky said at a NATO-related event Thursday in Prague that Ukraine needs resources to counter Russia's relentless assault.\n\n\"Ukraine cannot fight against Russia with one hand tied behind its back,\" he said. \"Ukraine must be able to fight against Russia's barbaric invasion even on Russian territory. Political resolve must be backed by credible capabilities.\"\n\nNorway's foreign minister, Espen Barth Eide, told Norwegian broadcaster NRK that his country believes Ukraine \"has a crystal-clear right under international law to attack Russia inside Russia as part of the defense of its territory.\"\n\nBiden's decision comes as he's set to travel to France early next month to attend D-Day 80th anniversary commemorations in Normandy, a watershed moment in changing the course of World War II. Zelenskyy is among dozens of world leaders expected to attend the D-Day commemorations.\n\n___", "source": {"uri": "wmur.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WMUR9"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"eng": "Volodymyr Zelenskyy"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kharkiv", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Kharkiv"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Kharkiv"}, "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ukraine", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Ukraine"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Ukraine"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russia", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Russia"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Russia"}}}, {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-374547658", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "13:35:44", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T13:35:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T11:27:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.brandonsun.com/local/2024/05/31/berlin-lets-ukraine-use-german-weapons-against-targets-in-russia-after-the-us-also-eases-its-stance", "title": "Berlin lets Ukraine use German weapons against targets in Russia after the US also eases its stance", "body": "KYIV, Ukraine (AP) -- Germany joined the United States on Friday in authorizing Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying -- a significant policy change that comes as depleted Ukrainian troops are losing ground in the war.\n\nUkrainian officials have expressed frustration over restrictions on the use of Western weapons -- especially as the border region of Kharkiv has endured a Russian onslaught this month that has stretched Kyiv's outgunned and outmanned forces.\n\nBoth Germany and the U.S. specifically authorized the use of weapons to defend Kharkiv, whose capital city of the same name lies only 20 kilometers (12 miles) from Russia. Russian ballistic missiles slammed into an apartment building in the city overnight, Ukrainian officials said, killing at least five people.\n\nBeyond offering Ukraine a chance of better protecting Kharkiv by targeting Russian capabilities in the region, it's not clear what effect the easing of restrictions might have on the direction of the conflict in what is proving to be a critical period. But it drew a furious response from Moscow and warnings it could draw Russia into war with NATO.\n\nThe German government said Ukraine can use weapons it supplies against positions just over the border, from where Russia launches its attacks on Kharkiv. A day earlier, U.S. President Joe Biden gave Kyiv a green light to strike back with American weapons at Russian military assets targeting the region, according to U.S. officials familiar with the matter.\n\nIn response, Dmitry Medvedev, the deputy head of Russia's Security Council, said Friday that \"Ukraine and its NATO allies will receive such a devastating response that the alliance won't be able to avoid entering the conflict\" -- an eventuality that Western governments have ruled out.\n\nWestern leaders have hesitated to ease the restrictions on their weapons because of the risk it would provoke Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has repeatedly warned that the West's direct involvement could put the world on a path to nuclear conflict. Last week, Russia said military drills involving tactical nuclear weapons had begun.\n\nBut as Russia has recently gained the battlefield initiative in some parts of the 1,000-kilometer (600-mile) front line, some Western leaders have pushed for a policy change allowing Kyiv to strike military bases inside Russia with sophisticated long-range weapons provided by its Western partners.\n\nThe Kremlin's bigger and better-equipped army is exploiting Ukrainian shortages in troops and ammunition after a lengthy delay in U.S. military aid. Western Europe's inadequate military production has also slowed crucial deliveries to Ukraine.\n\nThe German government statement noted that, in recent weeks, Russia has prepared, coordinated and carried out attacks on the Kharkiv region, in particular from areas just over the border in Russia.\n\n\"Together we are convinced that Ukraine has the right under international law to defend itself against these attacks,\" the statement said. \"For this, it can also use the weapons delivered for that purpose in accordance with its international legal commitments, including the ones delivered by us,\" it added.\n\nBiden's decision allows for U.S.-supplied weapons to be used for \"counterfire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" one official told The Associated Press.\n\nBut the officials, who requested anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, stressed that the U.S. policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.\n\nThe question of whether to allow Ukraine to hit targets on Russian soil with Western-supplied weaponry has been a delicate issue since Moscow launched its full-scale invasion on Feb. 24, 2022.\n\nNATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said Friday he supported lifting the limits on Ukraine's use of Western weaponry, saying it's \"a matter of upholding international law -- Ukraine's right to self-defense.\"\n\nSwedish Foreign Minister Tobias Billstr\u00f6m noted that his country had not restricted Ukraine's use of its weapons at all, while Italian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani said Rome won't let Kyiv use Italian weapons outside its territory.\n\nIn Moscow, Medvedev repeated Russian warnings that the steps being taken could set NATO and Russia on the path to a nuclear conflict. \"It's not an attempt to scare or any sort of a nuclear bluff,\" he said.\n\nRussia's newly appointed defense minister, Andrei Belousov, claimed Friday that Russian troops are \"advancing in all tactical directions,\" including in the Kharkiv region where he said they have pushed Ukrainian forces back by as much as 9 kilometers (5 miles). Russian forces captured 28 towns and villages over the past month, he said.\n\nOverall since the start of the year, Russian forces have taken control of 880 square kilometers (340 square miles) of territory, he added.\n\nIt was not possible to verify his battlefield claims.\n\nOvernight into Friday, Russia launched five ballistic missiles at Kharkiv, Ukraine's air force said. One of them struck a residential building close to midnight and was followed by another missile 25 minutes later that hit first responders, according to regional Gov. Oleh Syniehubov.\n\nFive people were killed, according to Kharkiv Mayor Ihor Terekhov, while the governor said at least 25 were wounded.\n\nUkrainian officials have previously accused Russia of targeting rescue workers by hitting residential buildings with two consecutive missiles -- the first one to draw emergency crews to the scene and the second one to wound or kill them. Russia used the method in Syria's civil war.\n\nApart from Kharkiv, Moscow's troops are pressing in the Donetsk region further south and are assembling a force for an expected attack in the Sumy region further north, according to Ukrainian officials.\n\n___\n\nLee and Janicek reported from Prague. Associated Press writers Geir Moulson in Berlin and Ellen Knickmeyer, Aamer Madhani and Zeke Miller in Washington contributed to this report.\n\n___\n\nFollow AP's coverage of the war in Ukraine at {"uri": "8154112048", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-30", "time": "22:21:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-30T22:21:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T22:19:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/2956088-bidens-bold-move-us-weapons-approved-for-strikes-inside-russia", "title": "Biden's Bold Move: U.S. Weapons Approved for Strikes Inside Russia | Politics", "body": "President Joe Biden has authorized Ukraine to use U.S.-supplied weapons against military targets inside Russia near the Kharkiv region. This marks a significant policy shift amidst the ongoing conflict with Russia. Although restricted to specific areas and weapon types, the decision reflects increased U.S. support for Ukraine.\n\nPresident Joe Biden quietly has authorized Kyiv to launch U.S.-supplied weapons at military targets inside Russia that are supporting an offensive against the northeastern Ukrainian city of Kharkiv, three U.S. officials said on Thursday.\n\nThe decision marks a policy shift by Biden, who had steadfastly refused to allow Ukraine to use American weaponry for strikes inside Russia. Russia's embassy in Washington and Russia's mission to the United Nations in New York did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nThe U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Biden's decision applies only to targets inside Russia near the border with the Kharkiv region, where an offensive launched by Moscow on May 10 has overrun some villages. \"The President recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use U.S.-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" said one U.S. official.\n\nRussia is building up forces near the northern part of the region, but it lacks the troop numbers to stage a major push, Ukraine's top commander said\n\non Thursday. Kharkiv, Ukraine's second largest city, is 19 miles (30 km) from the border with Russia.\n\nIt is the second time this year that Biden has quietly relaxed his policy on weapons supplies for Ukraine, bending\n\nto calls to send long-range missiles known as ATACMS to Kyiv. The U.S. is the biggest supplier of weapons to Ukraine in its battle against the full-scale invasion launched by Russian President Vladimir Putin in February 2022.\n\nThe officials said that U.S. policy would continue to prohibit the Ukrainian military from using ATACMS, which have a range of up to 186 miles (300 km), and other long-range U.S.-supplied weapons for deep strikes inside Russia. Nor does Biden's decision mean the U.S. now approves of drone attacks that Ukraine has been launching against Russian petroleum facilities, they said.\n\nSome NATO allies and U.S. lawmakers have been calling on Biden to relax the restriction on U.S. weapons to allow Ukraine to strike missile launchers and other military sites inside Russia that are backing Moscow's drive toward Kharkiv. Russia jetfighters flying inside Russia out of reach of Ukrainian air defenses have been supporting the offensive by loosing highly precise glide bombs at Ukrainian defense lines and into Kharkiv, where they have caused numerous civilian casualties.\n\nPutin on Tuesday warned NATO members against allowing Ukraine to fire their weapons into Russia and he raised anew a risk of nuclear war. Some experts dismissed his remarks as bluster. They noted that Putin has failed to act on similar threats in the past and already has committed the bulk of his conventional forces to Europe's biggest land war since World War II.\n\n\"I don't think we can or should be bullied by Vladimir Putin,\" said U.S. Representative Gerry Connolly, a Democratic member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. \"Is he really willing to risk nuclear war and a conflict with NATO?\" Connolly co-signed a May 20 letter with Representative Michael Turner, the Republican chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, and other lawmakers urging the administration to allow Ukraine to use U.S. weapons to hit strategic targets inside Russia.\n\nFor some time, critics have urged NATO allies to relax restrictions on use of their weapons against military targets inside Russia. Those voices have grown within the alliance since Russia launched the Kharkiv offensive. Countries that have called for relaxing restrictions or done so for their own arms sent to Ukraine include Britain, the Netherlands, Sweden, the Baltic states, Finland, Denmark, Germany and France.\n\nBiden faced the potentially embarrassing prospect that as he hosts a NATO summit in July, Russian forces would be advancing on Kharkiv and in Ukraine's east as the alliance marks its 75th anniversary, analysts said.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8154227306", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "00:46:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T00:46:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T00:45:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/2956133-biden-greenlights-defensive-strikes-inside-russia-using-us-weapons", "title": "Biden Greenlights Defensive Strikes Inside Russia Using US Weapons | Politics", "body": "President Joe Biden has authorized the use of U.S. weaponry for defensive strikes inside Russia to protect Kharkiv, Ukraine. The decision marks a shift in U.S. policy, previously wary of escalatory responses from Moscow. This move follows increased pressure from Ukrainian officials and allies like Macron and Stoltenberg.\n\nPresident Joe Biden has given Ukraine the go-ahead to use American weaponry to strike inside Russia for the limited purpose of defending Kharkiv, according to three US officials familiar with the matter.\n\nThe officials, who requested anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, underscored that the US policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.\n\nBiden's directive allows for US-supplied weapons to be used for ''counterfire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them'', one official said.\n\nThe move comes as Ukrainian officials have stepped up calls on the US administration to allow their forces to defend themselves against attacks originating from Russian territory. Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city, is just 20 kilometers (12 miles) from the Russian border.\n\nBiden's decision was first reported by Politico.\n\nUkrainian officials, most notably Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, have been increasingly vocal in arguing that the restriction was putting Ukrainian forces in an untenable situation as Russia intensified attacks around the northeast Kharkiv region.\n\nThe advances came with Russia exploiting a lengthy delay in replenishment of US military aid and as Western Europe's inadequate military production has slowed crucial deliveries to the battlefield for Ukraine.\n\nDuring Secretary of State Antony Blinken's visit to Kyiv two weeks ago, Zelenskyy made his case for using American weapons to strike back at positions in Russia that were launching attacks into north and northeast Ukraine.\n\nBlinken was convinced and brought that message back to Washington, but it was ultimately Biden's decision to make, according to three US officials who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss internal administration deliberations.\n\nSince the start of the Russian invasion in February 2022, Biden has been steadfast in his opposition to Ukraine's offensive use of American-made weaponry, concerned that the action could be seen as provocative and lead to Moscow widening the war.\n\nBlinken said in Moldova on Wednesday that US policy on how Ukraine deploys American weapons is constantly evolving, hinting that Washington may alter its unwritten prohibition on Ukraine's use of them for attacks on Russian territory. On Thursday, Blinken joined NATO foreign ministers for a meeting in Prague, where during a tour of a Czech military base he saw armored vehicles that are being sent to Kyiv.\n\nAlthough US officials insist there is no formal arms ban, they have long made clear that they believe the use of American weapons to attack targets inside Russia could provoke an escalatory response from Moscow, something that Russian President Vladimir Putin has promised.\n\nThat position, Blinken noted, was a \"hallmark\" of the Biden administration's stance on Ukraine to \"adapt and adjust\" as needed.\n\n\"As the conditions have changed, as the battlefield has changed, as what Russia does has changed in terms of how it's pursuing its aggression, escalation, we've adapted and adjusted, too, and I'm confident we'll continue to do that,\" Blinken said at a news conference in Moldova.\n\n\"We're always listening, we're always learning, and we're always making determinations about what's necessary to make sure that Ukraine can effectively continue to defend itself, and we'll continue to do that,'' he said.\n\nCalls for a change in policy have been mounting.\n\nEarlier this week, French President Emmanuel Macron and NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said that Western countries should not object if Ukraine needs to strike inside Russia to defend itself. Stoltenberg reaffirmed that position on Thursday.\n\n\"I believe that time has come to (re)consider some of these restrictions to enable the Ukrainians to really defend themselves,\" he said. \"We need to remember what it is. This is a war of aggression launched by choice by Moscow against Ukraine.\" The right to self-defence, he said, \"includes also striking legitimate military targets outside Ukraine\".\n\nCzech Foreign Minister Jan Lipavsky said at a NATO-related event on Thursday in Prague that Ukraine needs resources to counter Russia's relentless assault.\n\n\"Ukraine cannot fight against Russia with one hand tied behind its back,\" he said. \"Ukraine must be able to fight against Russia's barbaric invasion even on Russian territory. Political resolve must be backed by credible capabilities.\" Norway's foreign minister, Espen Barth Eide, told Norwegian broadcaster NRK that his country believes Ukraine \"has a crystal-clear right under international law to attack Russia inside Russia as part of the defence of its territory\".\n\nBiden's decision comes as he's set to travel to France early next month to attend D-Day 80th anniversary commemorations in Normandy, a watershed moment in changing the course of World War II. Zelenskyy is among dozens of world leaders expected to attend the D-Day commemorations.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", {"uri": "2024-05-374401551", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "11:21:57", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T11:21:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T06:05:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.infowars.com/posts/us-and-germany-authorize-ukrainian-attacks-against-russia", "title": "US and Germany Authorize Ukrainian Attacks Against Russia", "body": "Russia has warned that the decision marks an escalation of the war.\n\nBoth the United States and Germany have allowed weapons they supplied to Ukraine to be used against targets inside Russian territory. The two NATO member states have emphasised that their decision applies only to targets inside Russia near the border with the northeastern Ukrainian Kharkiv region, where Moscow launched an offensive a few weeks ago.\n\nU.S. President Joe Biden had been under pressure to authorise the decision, with Ukraine, the Baltic states, the Scandinavian countries, and Britain urging the United States to act. Biden had refused to do so, fearing that NATO could be dragged into a war with Russia, whose president, Vladimir Putin, warned the Western military alliance that they risked the outbreak of nuclear war.\n\nThe war between Ukraine and Russia, which started with the Russian invasion more than two years ago, has reached a stalemate in the past year Recently, Moscow launched an offensive against the Kharkiv region, which borders Russia, and Russian troops have made significant territorial gains there. Russian fighter planes flying inside Russia have been supporting the offensive by firing bombs at Ukrainian defence lines and into Kharkiv, reports Reuters.\n\nJoe Biden \"recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use U.S.-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" said one U.S. official.\n\nThe U.S. is the biggest supplier of weapons to Ukraine, and it recently decided to send long-range missiles known as ATACMS to Kyiv. Washington will continue to prohibit the Ukrainian military from using ATACMS, which have a range of up to 300 kilometres, for deep strikes inside Russia.\n\nGermany has also given into pressure, with government spokesman Steffen Hebestreit announcingon Friday that Berlin has given Kyiv permission to use weapons supplied by Germany against military targets in Russia. \"We are jointly convinced that Ukraine has the right under international law to defend itself against these attacks,\" he said.\n\nGerman policy on providing weapons has dramatically shifted, with Berlin initially only willing to send helmets to Ukraine at the beginning of Russia's invasion. Pressure by NATO allies, and from the hawkish Greens within the government, has persuaded Social Democrat Chancellor Olaf Scholz to allow the delivery of anti-aircraft systems and battle tanks. However, Scholz has refused to authorise the supply of long-range Taurus missiles, saying they could be used to hit targets deep inside Russia.\n\nNATO chief Jens Stoltenberg, who is attending the ongoing NATO foreign ministers' meeting in Prague, downplayed the threat of an escalation of the war. \"Ukraine has the right for self-defence, and that includes also the right to strike legitimate military targets inside Russia,\" he said on Friday. He added that letting Western weapons hit targets in Russia was \"nothing new\" as Britain had long sent cruise missiles to Kyiv without restrictions.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron also said on Tuesday that Ukraine should be allowed to \"neutralise\" bases in Russia used to launch strikes.\n\n\"NATO countries that have approved strikes with their weapons on Russian territory should be aware that their equipment and specialists will be destroyed not only in Ukraine, but also at any point from where Russian territory is attacked,\" former Russian president, now deputy chairman of the Russian Security Council Dmitry Medvedev warned on Friday. He said all long-range weapons supplied to Ukraine were already \"directly operated by servicemen from NATO countries,\" which is tantamount to participation in the war against Russia.", "source": {"uri": "8154726893", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "08:25:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T08:25:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T08:24:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2024/may/31/biden-expands-weapon-use-for-ukraine/", "title": "Biden expands weapon use for Ukraine", "body": "WASHINGTON -- President Joe Biden has given Ukraine the go-ahead to use American weaponry to strike inside Russia for the limited purpose of defending Kharkiv, according to three U.S. officials familiar with the matter.\n\nThe officials, who requested anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, underscored that the U.S. policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.\n\nBiden's directive allows for U.S.-supplied weapons to be used for \"counterfire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" one official said.\n\nThe move comes as Ukrainian officials have stepped up calls on the U.S. administration to allow their forces to defend themselves against attacks originating from Russian territory. Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city, is just 12 miles from the Russian border.\n\nBiden's decision was first reported by Politico.\n\nUkrainian officials, most notably Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, have been increasingly vocal in arguing that the restriction was putting Ukrainian forces in an untenable situation as Russia intensified attacks around the northeast Kharkiv region.\n\nThe advances came with Russia exploiting a lengthy delay in replenishment of U.S. military aid and as Western Europe's inadequate military production has slowed crucial deliveries to the battlefield for Ukraine.\n\nDuring Secretary of State Antony Blinken's visit to Kyiv two weeks ago, Zelenskyy made his case for using American weapons to strike back at positions in Russia that were launching attacks into north and northeast Ukraine.\n\nBlinken was convinced and brought that message back to Washington, but it was ultimately Biden's decision to make, according to three U.S. officials who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss internal administration deliberations.\n\nSince the start of the Russian invasion in February 2022, Biden has been steadfast in his opposition to Ukraine's offensive use of American-made weaponry, concerned that the action could be seen as provocative and lead to Moscow widening the war.\n\nBlinken said in Moldova on Wednesday that U.S. policy on how Ukraine deploys American weapons is constantly evolving, hinting that Washington may alter its unwritten prohibition on Ukraine's use of them for attacks on Russian territory. On Thursday, Blinken joined NATO foreign ministers for a meeting in Prague, where during a tour of a Czech military base he saw armored vehicles that are being sent to Kyiv.\n\nAlthough U.S. officials insist there is no formal arms ban, they have long made clear that they believe the use of American weapons to attack targets inside Russia could provoke an escalatory response from Moscow, something that Russian President Vladimir Putin has promised.\n\nThat position, Blinken noted, was a \"hallmark\" of the Biden administration's stance on Ukraine to \"adapt and adjust\" as needed.\n\n\"As the conditions have changed, as the battlefield has changed, as what Russia does has changed in terms of how it's pursuing its aggression, escalation, we've adapted and adjusted, too, and I'm confident we'll continue to do that,\" Blinken said at a news conference in Moldova.\n\n\"We're always listening, we're always learning, and we're always making determinations about what's necessary to make sure that Ukraine can effectively continue to defend itself, and we'll continue to do that,\" he said.\n\nCalls for a change in policy have been mounting.\n\nEarlier this week, French President Emmanuel Macron and NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said that Western countries should not object if Ukraine needs to strike inside Russia to defend itself. Stoltenberg reaffirmed that position on Thursday.\n\n\"I believe that time has come to (re)consider some of these restrictions to enable the Ukrainians to really defend themselves,\" he said. \"We need to remember what it is. This is a war of aggression launched by choice by Moscow against Ukraine.\"\n\nThe right to self-defense, he said, \"includes also striking legitimate military targets outside Ukraine.\"\n\nCzech Foreign Minister Jan Lipavsky said at a NATO-related event Thursday in Prague that Ukraine needs resources to counter Russia's relentless assault.\n\n\"Ukraine cannot fight against Russia with one hand tied behind its back,\" he said. \"Ukraine must be able to fight against Russia's barbaric invasion even on Russian territory. Political resolve must be backed by credible capabilities.\"\n\nNorway's foreign minister, Espen Barth Eide, told Norwegian broadcaster NRK that his country believes Ukraine \"has a crystal-clear right under international law to attack Russia inside Russia as part of the defense of its territory.\"\n\nInformation for this article was contributed by Karel Janicek and Ellen Knickmeyer of The {"uri": "8154137823", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-30", "time": "22:53:10", "dateTime": "2024-05-30T22:53:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T22:52:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.unionleader.com/news/military/biden-allows-ukraine-limited-use-of-us-arms-to-strike-inside-russia-say-us-officials/article_d9cc5ebc-aea7-5cd8-b194-fe68a7c68d02.html", "title": "Biden allows Ukraine limited use of US arms to strike inside Russia, say US officials", "body": "President Joe Biden quietly has authorized Kyiv to launch U.S.-supplied weapons at military targets inside Russia that are supporting an offensive against the northeastern Ukrainian city of Kharkiv, three U.S. officials said on Thursday.\n\nThe decision marks a policy shift by Biden, who had steadfastly refused to allow Ukraine to use American weaponry for strikes inside Russia.\n\nRussia's embassy in Washington and Russia's mission to the United Nations in New York did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nThe U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Biden's decision applies only to targets inside Russia near the border with the Kharkiv region, where an offensive launched by Moscow on May 10 has overrun some villages.\n\n\"The President recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use U.S.-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" said one U.S. official.\n\nRussia is building up forces near the northern part of the region, but it lacks the troop numbers to stage a major push, Ukraine's top commander said on Thursday.\n\nKharkiv, Ukraine's second largest city, is 19 miles from the border with Russia.\n\nIt is the second time this year that Biden has quietly relaxed his policy on weapons supplies for Ukraine, bending to calls to send long-range missiles known as ATACMS to Kyiv.\n\nThe U.S. is the biggest supplier of weapons to Ukraine in its battle against the full-scale invasion launched by Russian President Vladimir Putin in February 2022.\n\nThe officials said that U.S. policy would continue to prohibit the Ukrainian military from using ATACMS, which have a range of up to 186 miles, and other long-range U.S.-supplied weapons for deep strikes inside Russia.\n\nNor does Biden's decision mean the U.S. now approves of drone attacks that Ukraine has been launching against Russian petroleum facilities, they said.\n\nSome NATO allies and U.S. lawmakers have been calling on Biden to relax the restriction on U.S. weapons to allow Ukraine to strike missile launchers and other military sites inside Russia that are backing Moscow's drive toward Kharkiv.\n\nRussian jet fighters flying inside Russia out of reach of Ukrainian air defenses have been supporting the offensive by loosing highly precise glide bombs at Ukrainian defense lines and into Kharkiv, where they have caused numerous civilian casualties.\n\nPutin on Tuesday warned NATO members against allowing Ukraine to fire their weapons into Russia and he raised anew a risk of nuclear war.\n\nSome experts dismissed his remarks as bluster. They noted that Putin has failed to act on similar threats in the past and already has committed the bulk of his conventional forces to Europe's biggest land war since World War II.\n\n\"I don't think we can or should be bullied by Vladimir Putin,\" said U.S. Rep. Gerry Connolly, a Democratic member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. \"Is he really willing to risk nuclear war and a conflict with NATO?\"\n\nConnolly co-signed a May 20 letter with Rep. Michael Turner, the Republican chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, and other lawmakers urging the administration to allow Ukraine to use U.S. weapons to hit strategic targets inside Russia.\n\nFor some time, critics have urged NATO allies to relax restrictions on use of their weapons against military targets inside Russia. Those voices have grown within the alliance since Russia launched the Kharkiv offensive.\n\nCountries that have called for relaxing restrictions or done so for their own arms sent to Ukraine include Britain, the Netherlands, Sweden, the Baltic states, Finland, Denmark, Germany and France.\n\nBiden faced the potentially embarrassing prospect that as he hosts a NATO summit in July, Russian forces would be advancing on Kharkiv and in Ukraine's east as the alliance marks its 75th anniversary, analysts said.", "source": {"uri": "unionleader.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "UnionLeader.com"}, "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.latinpost.com/articles/163164/20240530/joe-biden-greenlights-ukraine-strike-russia-american-weapons.htm", "title": "Joe Biden Greenlights Ukraine to Strike Russia with American Weapons", "body": "In a major policy change, the Joe Biden administration has quietly allowed Ukraine to use provided American weapons to strike Russian territory near Kharkiv.\n\nThis decision aims to strengthen Ukraine's defense of its second-largest city against Russian advances, Politico reports.\n\nThe permission, confirmed by US officials, enables Ukraine to target Russian forces attacking or preparing to attack Kharkiv.\n\nHowever, the policy still prohibits long-range strikes deep inside Russia.\n\nA US official noted that President Joe Biden directed his team to support Ukraine's counter-fire efforts in response to Russia's recent intensified offensive on Kharkiv.\n\nREAD NEXT: Joe Biden Opens Door for Cuban Small Businesses to Access US Online Banking\n\nRecently, the US granted Ukraine the flexibility to use American weapons, such as rockets and launchers, to defend itself from border attacks near Kharkiv.\n\nThese weapons can intercept Russian missiles, target troop concentrations, and engage bombers launching attacks on Ukrainian territory.\n\nHowever, Ukraine is restricted from using these weapons against civilian infrastructure or conducting long-range strikes inside Russia, according to CNN.\n\nThe shift in US policy, initially seen as a potential escalation, was driven by worsening battlefield conditions and Russian advances in Kharkiv.\n\nThe National Security Council has not commented on the change.\n\nSecretary of State Antony Blinken suggested US policy toward Ukraine would evolve, and National Security Council spokesperson John Kirby did not rule out a policy change.\n\nTop US allies like the UK and France support Ukraine's right to use Western weapons for strikes inside Russia.\n\nBipartisan Congressional support exists, with military officials briefing Congress on the strategic value of such strikes.\n\nSome US officials worry about Ukraine using drones for unrelated military targets.\n\nThe US stresses that American weapons should target military sites directly involved in the invasion, not civilian infrastructure.\n\nUkrainian leaders, including President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, have pressed the Joe Biden administration to change its policy, arguing that not targeting Russian troop positions across the border complicates their defense.\n\nIn a conversation with Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin, Ukrainian Defense Minister Rustem Umerov advocated for using American weapons inside Russia to defend Kharkiv.\n\nPresident Joe Biden's decision is limited to areas near Kharkiv, and Ukraine has not requested broader permissions.\n\nThe US maintains its prohibition on using long-range missiles, such as the Army Tactical Missile System (ATACMS), for deep strikes inside Russia.\n\nEuropean leaders, including French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, support Ukraine's use of Western weapons for self-defense.\n\nMacron emphasized targeting bases in Russia from which attacks on Ukraine are launched, Reuters noted.\n\nNATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg urged the US and allies to provide Ukraine with the necessary capabilities to defend itself without limitations, including striking legitimate military targets in Russia.\n\nThe Joe Biden administration's decision reflects growing international pressure and changing battlefield conditions.\n\nWhile Ukraine can use American weapons near Kharkiv, it remains prohibited from using long-range weapons like ATACMS for deep strikes inside Russia.\n\nThis decision does not endorse Ukraine's drone attacks on Russian petroleum facilities but is a significant step in supporting Ukraine's defense against Russian aggression near Kharkiv.\n\nInternational {"uri": "8154088327", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-30", "time": "21:54:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-30T21:54:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T21:53:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/biden-partially-lifts-ban-on-ukraine-using-u-s-arms-in-strikes-on-russian-territory-u-s-officials-say-1.6907346", "title": "Biden partially lifts ban on Ukraine using U.S. arms in strikes on Russian territory, U.S. officials say", "body": "U.S. President Joe Biden has given Ukraine the go-ahead to use American weaponry to strike inside Russia for the limited purpose of defending Kharkiv, according to three U.S. officials familiar with the matter.\n\nThe officials, who requested anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, underscored that the U.S. policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.\n\nBiden's directive allows for U.S.-supplied weapons to be used for \"counterfire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" one official said.\n\nThe move comes as Ukrainian officials have stepped up calls on the U.S. administration to allow its forces to defend itself against attacks originating from Russian territory. Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city, is just 20 kilometres (12 miles) from the Russian border.\n\nBiden's decision was first reported by Politico.\n\nUkrainian officials, most notably Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, have been increasingly vocal in arguing that the restriction was putting Ukrainian forces in an untenable situation as Russia intensified attacks around the northeast Kharkiv region.\n\nThe advances came with Russia exploiting a lengthy delay in replenishment of U.S. military aid and as Western Europe's inadequate military production has slowed crucial deliveries to the battlefield for Ukraine.\n\nDuring Secretary of State Antony Blinken's visit to Kyiv two weeks ago, Zelenskyy made his case for using American weapons to strike back at positions in Russia that were launching attacks into north and northeast Ukraine, according to three U.S. officials who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss internal administration deliberations.\n\nBlinken was convinced and brought that message back to Washington, but it was ultimately Biden's decision to make, the officials said.\n\nSince the start of the Russian invasion in February 2022, Biden has been steadfast in his opposition to Ukraine's offensive use of American-made weaponry, concerned that the action could be seen as provocative and lead to Moscow widening the war.\n\nBlinken said in Moldova on Wednesday that U.S. policy on how Ukraine deploys American weapons is constantly evolving, hinting that Washington may alter its unwritten prohibition on Ukraine's use of them for attacks on Russian territory.\n\nAlthough U.S. officials insist there is no formal ban, they have long made clear that they believe the use of American weapons to attack targets inside Russia could provoke an escalatory response from Moscow, something that Russian President Vladimir Putin has promised.\n\nThat position, Blinken noted, was a \"hallmark\" of the Biden administration's stance on Ukraine to \"adapt and adjust\" as needed. Blinken visited Kyiv earlier this month and heard a direct appeal from Zelenskyy to use U.S. military assistance to strike positions in Russian from where attacks on Ukraine are launched.\n\n\"As the conditions have changed, as the battlefield has changed, as what Russia does has changed in terms of how it's pursuing its aggression, escalation, we've adapted and adjusted too, and I'm confident we'll continue to do that,\" Blinken said at a news conference in Moldova.\n\n\"At every step along the way, we've adapted and adjusted as necessary, and so that's exactly what we'll do going forward,\" he said. \"We're always listening, we're always learning, and we're always making determinations about what's necessary to make sure that Ukraine can effectively continue to defend itself, and we'll continue to do that.\"\n\nCalls for a change in policy have been mounting.\n\nEarlier this week, French President Emmanuel Macron and NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said that Western countries should not object if Ukraine needs to strike inside Russia to defend itself. Stoltenberg reaffirmed that position on Thursday.\n\n\"I believe that time has come to (re)consider some of these restrictions to enable the Ukrainians to really defend themselves,\" he said. \"We need to remember what it is. This is a war of aggression launched by choice by Moscow against Ukraine.\"\n\nThe right to self-defence, he said, \" includes also striking legitimate military targets outside Ukraine.\"\n\nCzech Foreign Minister Minister Jan Lipavsky at NATO-related event on Thursday Ukraine needs resources to counter Russia's relentless assault.\n\n\"Ukraine cannot fight against Russia with one hand tied behind its back,\" he said. \"Ukraine must be able to fight against Russia's barbaric invasion even on Russian territory. Political resolve must be backed by credible capabilities.\"\n\nNorway's foreign minister, Espen Barth Eide, told Norwegian broadcaster NRK that his country believes Ukraine \"has a crystal-clear right under international law to attack Russia inside Russia as part of the defence of its territory.\"\n\nBiden's decision comes as he's set to travel to France early next month to attend D-Day 80th anniversary commemorations in Normandy, a watershed moment in changing the course of World War II. Zelenskyy is among dozens of world leaders expected to attend to attend the D-Day commemorations.", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTV News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8155048983", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "11:48:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T11:48:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T11:47:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/us-world/berlin-lets-ukraine-use-german-weapons-against-targets-in-russia-after-the-us-also-eases-its-stance/", "title": "Berlin lets Ukraine use German weapons against targets in Russia after the US also eases its stance - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "KYIV, Ukraine (AP) -- Germany joined the United States on Friday in authorizing Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying -- a significant policy change that comes as depleted Ukrainian troops are losing ground in the war.\n\nUkrainian officials have expressed frustration over restrictions on the use of Western weapons -- especially as the border region of Kharkiv has endured a Russian onslaught this month that has stretched Kyiv's outgunned and outmanned forces.\n\nBoth Germany and the U.S. specifically authorized defense of Kharkiv, whose capital city of the same name lies only 20 kilometers (12 miles) from Russia. Russian ballistic missiles slammed into an apartment building in the city overnight, killing at least four people.\n\nBeyond offering Ukraine a chance of better protecting Kharkiv, it's not clear what effect the easing of restrictions might have on the direction of the conflict in what is proving to be a critical period.\n\nThe German government said Ukraine can use weapons it supplies against positions just over the border, from where Russia launches its attacks on Kharkiv. A day earlier, U.S. President Joe Biden gave Kyiv a green light to strike back with American weapons at Russian military assets targeting the region, according to U.S. officials familiar with the matter.\n\nThe German announcement brought a furious response from Moscow, where Dmitry Medvedev, the deputy head of Russia's Security Council, said that \"Ukraine and its NATO allies will receive such a devastating response that the alliance won't be able to avoid entering the conflict\" -- an eventuality that Western governments have ruled out.\n\nWestern leaders have hesitated to ease the restrictions on their weapons because of the risk it would provoke Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has repeatedly warned that the West's direct involvement could put the world on a path to nuclear conflict.\n\nBut as Russia has recently gained the battlefield initiative in some parts of the 1,000-kilometer (600-mile) front line, some Western leaders have pushed for a policy change allowing Kyiv to strike military bases inside Russia with sophisticated long-range weapons provided by its Western partners.\n\nThe Kremlin's bigger and better-equipped army is exploiting Ukrainian shortages in troops and ammunition after a lengthy delay in U.S. military aid. Western Europe's inadequate military production has also slowed crucial deliveries to Ukraine.\n\nThe German government statement noted that, in recent weeks, Russia has prepared, coordinated and carried out attacks on the Kharkiv region, in particular from areas just over the border in Russia.\n\n\"Together we are convinced that Ukraine has the right under international law to defend itself against these attacks,\" the statement said. \"For this, it can also use the weapons delivered for that purpose in accordance with its international legal commitments, including the ones delivered by us,\" it added, without elaborating on what Berlin called confidential agreements with Kyiv.\n\nBiden's decision allows for U.S.-supplied weapons to be used for \"counterfire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" one official told The Associated Press.\n\nBut the officials, who requested anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, stressed that the U.S. policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.\n\nThe question of whether to allow Ukraine to hit targets on Russian soil with Western-supplied weaponry has been a delicate issue since Moscow launched its full-scale invasion on Feb. 24, 2022.\n\nNATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said Friday he supported lifting the limits on Ukraine's use of Western weaponry, saying it's \"a matter of upholding international law -- Ukraine's right to self-defense.\"\n\nSwedish Foreign Minister Tobias Billstrom noted that his country had not restricted Ukraine's use of its weapons at all, while Italian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani said Rome won't let Kyiv use Italian weapons outside its territory.\n\nIn Moscow, Medvedev repeated Russian warnings that the steps being taken could set NATO and Russia on the path to a nuclear conflict. \"It's not an attempt to scare or any sort of a nuclear bluff,\" he said.\n\nRussia's newly appointed defense minister, Andrei Belousov, claimed Friday that Russian troops are \"advancing in all tactical directions,\" including in the Kharkiv region where he said they have pushed Ukrainian forces back by as much as 9 kilometers (5 miles). Russian forces captured 28 towns and villages over the past month, he said.\n\nOverall since the start of the year, Russian forces have taken control of 880 square kilometers (340 square miles) of territory, he added.\n\nIt was not possible to verify his battlefield claims.\n\nOvernight into Friday, Russia launched five ballistic missiles at Kharkiv, Ukraine's air force said. One of them struck a residential building close to midnight and was followed by another missile 25 minutes later that hit first responders, according to regional Gov. Oleh Syniehubov. At least 25 people were injured, he said.\n\nUkrainian officials have previously accused Russia of targeting rescue workers by hitting residential buildings with two consecutive missiles -- the first one to draw emergency crews to the scene and the second one to wound or kill them. Russia used the method in Syria's civil war.\n\nApart from Kharkiv, Moscow's troops are pressing in the Donetsk region further south and are assembling a force for an expected attack in the Sumy region further north, according to Ukrainian officials.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. But the official said Ukraine cannot use those weapons to hit civilian infrastructure or launch long-range missiles, such as the Army Tactical Missile System, to hit military targets deep inside Russia.\n\nPer Reuters:\n\nRussia's embassy in Washington and Russia's mission to the United Nations in New York did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nNATO allies have been calling on the U.S. to allow Ukraine to use Western weapons against missile launchers and other military sites inside Russia that are supporting a cross-border offensive that Moscow launched toward Kharkiv this month.\n\nRussia jetfighters flying inside Russia have been backing the drive by launching glide bombs at Kharkiv and Ukrainian defense lines.\n\nWord of Biden's decision broke shortly after the Pentagon said the U.S. policy against use of U.S. weapons inside Russia had remained unchanged.\n\n\"The security assistance that we provide Ukraine is to be used within Ukraine. {"uri": "8154159069", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-30", "time": "23:19:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-30T23:19:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T23:18:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.thedailystar.net/news/world/russian-invasion-ukraine/news/biden-allows-ukraine-limited-use-us-arms-strike-inside-russia-3623471", "title": "Biden allows Ukraine limited use of US arms to strike inside Russia", "body": "President Joe Biden quietly has authorised Kyiv to launch US-supplied weapons at military targets inside Russia that are supporting an offensive against the northeastern Ukrainian city of Kharkiv, three US officials said on Thursday.\n\nThe decision marks a policy shift by Biden, who had steadfastly refused to allow Ukraine to use American weaponry for strikes inside Russia.\n\nRussia's embassy in Washington and Russia's mission to the United Nations in New York did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nThe US officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Biden's decision applies only to targets inside Russia near the border with the Kharkiv region, where an offensive launched by Moscow on May 10 has overrun some villages.\n\n\"The President recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use US-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" said one US official.\n\nRussia is building up forces near the northern part of the region, but it lacks the troop numbers to stage a major push, Ukraine's top commander said on Thursday.\n\nKharkiv, Ukraine's second largest city, is 19 miles (30km) from the border with Russia.\n\nIt is the second time this year that Biden has quietly relaxed his policy on weapons supplies for Ukraine, bending to calls to send long-range missiles known as ATACMS to Kyiv.\n\nThe US is the biggest supplier of weapons to Ukraine in its battle against the full-scale invasion launched by Russian President Vladimir Putin in February 2022.\n\nThe officials said that US policy would continue to prohibit the Ukrainian military from using ATACMS, which have a range of up to 186 miles (300 km), and other long-range US-supplied weapons for deep strikes inside Russia.\n\nNor does Biden's decision mean the US now approves of drone attacks that Ukraine has been launching against Russian petroleum facilities, they said.\n\nSome NATO allies and US lawmakers have been calling on Biden to relax the restriction on US weapons to allow Ukraine to strike missile launchers and other military sites inside Russia that are backing Moscow's drive toward Kharkiv.\n\nRussia jetfighters flying inside Russia out of reach of Ukrainian air defenses have been supporting the offensive by loosing highly precise glide bombs at Ukrainian defense lines and into Kharkiv, where they have caused numerous civilian casualties.\n\nPutin on Tuesday warned NATO members against allowing Ukraine to fire their weapons into Russia and he raised anew a risk of nuclear war.\n\nSome experts dismissed his remarks as bluster. They noted that Putin has failed to act on similar threats in the past and already has committed the bulk of his conventional forces to Europe's biggest land war since World War II.\n\n\"I don't think we can or should be bullied by Vladimir Putin,\" said US Representative Gerry Connolly, a Democratic member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. \"Is he really willing to risk nuclear war and a conflict with NATO?\"\n\nConnolly co-signed a May 20 letter with Representative Michael Turner, the Republican chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, and other lawmakers urging the administration to allow Ukraine to use US weapons to hit strategic targets inside Russia.\n\nFor some time, critics have urged NATO allies to relax restrictions on use of their weapons against military targets inside Russia. Those voices have grown within the alliance since Russia launched the Kharkiv offensive.\n\nCountries that have called for relaxing restrictions or done so for their own arms sent to Ukraine include Britain, the Netherlands, Sweden, the Baltic states, Finland, Denmark, Germany and France.\n\nBiden faced the potentially embarrassing prospect that as he hosts a NATO summit in July, Russian forces {"uri": "8155043426", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "11:45:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T11:45:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T11:44:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.ctvnews.ca/world/berlin-lets-ukraine-use-german-weapons-against-targets-in-russia-after-the-u-s-also-eases-its-stance-1.6907976", "title": "Berlin lets Ukraine use German weapons against targets in Russia after the U.S. also eases its stance", "body": "Germany joined the United States on Friday in authorizing Ukraine to hit some targets on Russian soil with the long-range weapons they are supplying -- a significant policy change that comes as depleted Ukrainian troops are losing ground in the war.\n\nUkrainian officials have expressed frustration over restrictions on the use of Western weapons -- especially as the border region of Kharkiv has endured a Russian onslaught this month that has stretched Kyiv's outgunned and outmanned forces.\n\nBoth Germany and the U.S. specifically authorized defence of Kharkiv, whose capital city of the same name lies only 20 kilometres (12 miles) from Russia. Russian ballistic missiles slammed into an apartment building in the city overnight, killing at least four people.\n\nBeyond offering Ukraine a chance of better protecting Kharkiv, it's not clear what effect the easing of restrictions might have on the direction of the conflict in what is proving to be a critical period.\n\nThe German government said Ukraine can use weapons it supplies against positions just over the border, from where Russia launches its attacks on Kharkiv. A day earlier, U.S. President Joe Biden gave Kyiv a green light to strike back with American weapons at Russian military assets targeting the region, according to U.S. officials familiar with the matter.\n\nThe German announcement brought a furious response from Moscow, where Dmitry Medvedev, the deputy head of Russia's Security Council, said that \"Ukraine and its NATO allies will receive such a devastating response that the alliance won't be able to avoid entering the conflict\" -- an eventuality that Western governments have ruled out.\n\nWestern leaders have hesitated to ease the restrictions on their weapons because of the risk it would provoke Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has repeatedly warned that the West's direct involvement could put the world on a path to nuclear conflict.\n\nBut as Russia has recently gained the battlefield initiative in some parts of the 1,000-kilometer (600-mile) front line, some Western leaders have pushed for a policy change allowing Kyiv to strike military bases inside Russia with sophisticated long-range weapons provided by its Western partners.\n\nThe Kremlin's bigger and better-equipped army is exploiting Ukrainian shortages in troops and ammunition after a lengthy delay in U.S. military aid. Western Europe's inadequate military production has also slowed crucial deliveries to Ukraine.\n\nThe German government statement noted that, in recent weeks, Russia has prepared, coordinated and carried out attacks on the Kharkiv region, in particular from areas just over the border in Russia.\n\n\"Together we are convinced that Ukraine has the right under international law to defend itself against these attacks,\" the statement said. \"For this, it can also use the weapons delivered for that purpose in accordance with its international legal commitments, including the ones delivered by us,\" it added, without elaborating on what Berlin called confidential agreements with Kyiv.\n\nBiden's decision allows for U.S.-supplied weapons to be used for \"counterfire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" one official told The Associated Press.\n\nBut the officials, who requested anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, stressed that the U.S. policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.\n\nThe question of whether to allow Ukraine to hit targets on Russian soil with Western-supplied weaponry has been a delicate issue since Moscow launched its full-scale invasion on Feb. 24, 2022.\n\nNATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said Friday he supported lifting the limits on Ukraine's use of Western weaponry, saying it's \"a matter of upholding international law -- Ukraine's right to self-defence.\"\n\nSwedish Foreign Minister Tobias Billstrom noted that his country had not restricted Ukraine's use of its weapons at all, while Italian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani said Rome won't let Kyiv use Italian weapons outside its territory.\n\nIn Moscow, Medvedev repeated Russian warnings that the steps being taken could set NATO and Russia on the path to a nuclear conflict. \"It's not an attempt to scare or any sort of a nuclear bluff,\" he said.\n\nRussia's newly appointed defence minister, Andrei Belousov, claimed Friday that Russian troops are \"advancing in all tactical directions,\" including in the Kharkiv region where he said they have pushed Ukrainian forces back by as much as 9 kilometres (5 miles). Russian forces captured 28 towns and villages over the past month, he said.\n\nOverall since the start of the year, Russian forces have taken control of 880 square kilometres (340 square miles) of territory, he added.\n\nIt was not possible to verify his battlefield claims.\n\nOvernight into Friday, Russia launched five ballistic missiles at Kharkiv, Ukraine's air force said. One of them struck a residential building close to midnight and was followed by another missile 25 minutes later that hit first responders, according to regional Gov. Oleh Syniehubov. At least 25 people were injured, he said.\n\nUkrainian officials have previously accused Russia of targeting rescue workers by hitting residential buildings with two consecutive missiles -- the first one to draw emergency crews to the scene and the second one to wound or kill them. Russia used the method in Syria's civil war.\n\nApart from Kharkiv, Moscow's troops are pressing in the Donetsk region further south and are assembling a force for an expected attack in the Sumy region further north, according to Ukrainian officials.", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTV News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": They added that US policy on longer range strikes inside Russia \"has not changed.\"\n\nThe official said Ukraine requested this limited change in policy after Russia began its offensive on Kharkiv earlier this month. A second official said the US made the decision in the last few days to allow Ukraine to be more flexible in how it defends itself from attacks close to the border.\n\nUkraine will now be able to use US rockets and rocket launchers to take down Russian missiles moving toward Kharkiv, to attack troops gathering just over the border close to the city, as well as Russian bombers.\n\nBut Ukraine cannot use US weaponry to strike civilian infrastructure or launch long-range missiles, the official said, according to Politico. It also cannot strike military targets far inside Russia's borders.\n\nThe administration previously said this kind of change would escalate the war by further involving the US, but Ukraine's dire situation on the battlefield prompted Biden to change course.\n\nSecretary of State Antony Blinken said on Wednesday that Biden may change his mind on the matter, saying that US policy would change as needed. John Kirby, the White House National Security Council spokesperson, also did not rule out a policy change.\n\nThis comes after US allies, including the UK and France, said Ukraine should be allowed to strike inside Russia using weapons supplied by the West. Both Democrats and Republicans have also backed the move in public and behind the scenes.\n\nA number of officials have been concerned that Ukraine has struck military targets not used in the invasion when using its own drones and the US has emphasized that Ukraine may only use US weapons to strike military targets actively used in the invasion.\n\nPresident Volodymyr Zelensky and other Ukrainian officials have argued for a policy change since Russia started its attack on Kharkiv, saying that for weeks, Ukrainian defense of Kharkiv and the rest of the country has been stymied by their inability to strike Russian troop positions just over the border.\n\nUkrainian Defense Minister Rustem Umerov pushed hard to be able to use US weapons in Russia when speaking to US Defense Secretary And we don't encourage attacks, or enable attacks, inside of Russia,\" said Pentagon spokesperson Sabrina Singh.\n\nUS Secretary of State Antony Blinken had hinted on Wednesday that Biden could change course on the previous prohibition on striking targets within Russia.\n\nBlinken said the United States had \"adapted and adjusted\" as the \"battlefield has changed,\" as he spoke to reporters on a visit to Moldova on the eve of NATO talks in Prague.\n\nBlinken, who traveled Kyiv earlier this month to see the increasingly grave situation as Russia pushes forward towards Kharkiv, had been widely reported to be pressing Biden to ease the rules.\n\nAhead of the NATO meeting, which starts with a dinner on Thursday, alliance chief Jens Stoltenberg said repeatedly it was time for members to reconsider those limits because they hampered Kyiv's ability to defend itself.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron appeared to shift the dial forward on Tuesday when he said Ukraine should be allowed to \"neutralize\" bases in Russia used to launch strikes.\n\nGerman Chancellor Olaf Scholz, however, remained less sure, saying Ukraine should act within the law -- and Berlin had not supplied weapons
