"sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.westhawaiitoday.com/2024/05/31/nation-world-news/biden-allows-ukraine-limited-use-of-us-arms-to-strike-inside-russia-say-us-officials/", "title": "Biden allows Ukraine limited use of US arms to strike inside Russia, say US officials - West Hawaii Today", "body": "WASHINGTON/PRAGUE -- President Joe Biden quietly has authorized Kyiv to launch U.S.-supplied weapons at military targets inside Russia that are supporting an offensive against the northeastern Ukrainian city of Kharkiv, four U.S. officials said on Thursday.\n\nThe decision marks a policy shift by Biden, who had steadfastly refused to allow Ukraine to use American weaponry for strikes inside Russia.\n\nRussia's embassy in Washington and Russia's mission to the United Nations in New York did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nThe U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Biden's decision applies only to targets inside Russia near the border with the Kharkiv region, where an offensive launched by Moscow on May 10 has overrun some villages.\n\n\"The President recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use U.S.-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" said one U.S. official.\n\nRussia is building up forces near the northern part of the region, but it lacks the troop numbers to stage a major push, Ukraine's top commander said on Thursday.\n\nKharkiv, Ukraine's second largest city, is 19 miles (30 km) from the border with Russia.\n\nIt is the second time this year that Biden has quietly relaxed his policy on weapons supplies for Ukraine, bending to calls to send long-range missiles known as ATACMS to Kyiv.\n\n\"The Biden administration has come a long way from their hypersensitivity to and misunderstanding of the risk of escalation,\" said Alexander Vindman, a retired Army lieutenant colonel and former director for European affairs at the White House National Security Council under the Trump administration.\n\nHe applauded the shift in Biden's policy, which he said \"unties Ukraine's hands.\"\n\n\"Of course it's the right move,\" Vindman said.\n\nThe U.S. is the biggest supplier of weapons to Ukraine in its battle against the full-scale invasion launched by Russian President Vladimir Putin in February 2022.\n\nThe officials said that U.S. policy would continue to prohibit the Ukrainian military from using ATACMS, which have a range of up to 186 miles (300 km), and other long-range U.S.-supplied weapons for deep strikes inside Russia.\n\nBiden's decision also does not mean the U.S. now approves of drone attacks that Ukraine has been launching against Russian petroleum facilities, they said.\n\nSome NATO allies and U.S. lawmakers have been calling on Biden to relax the restriction on U.S. weapons to allow Ukraine to strike missile launchers and other military sites inside Russia that are backing Moscow's drive toward Kharkiv.\n\nRussia jetfighters flying inside Russia out of reach of Ukrainian air defenses have been supporting the offensive by loosing highly precise glide bombs at Ukrainian defense lines and into Kharkiv, where they have caused numerous civilian casualties.\n\nPutin on Tuesday warned NATO members against allowing Ukraine to fire their weapons into Russia and he raised anew a risk of nuclear war.\n\nSome experts dismissed his remarks as bluster.\n\nThey noted that Putin has failed to act on similar threats in the past and already has committed the bulk of his conventional forces to Europe's biggest land war since World War Two.", "source": {"uri": "westhawaiitoday.com", "dataType": "news", They maintained, however, that restrictions on using US weapons to strike targets deep inside of Russia remain in place.\n\nThe revised limitations come after Russia renewed offensive efforts to seize Kharkiv earlier this month, and an official said Ukraine asked for them in the wake of Russia's effort.\n\nUkraine is now able to use US weapons to carry out a number of attacks against Russia, including hitting rockets and rocket launchers near Kharkiv, downing missiles bound for the city, striking Russian troops amassing along the border, and shooting at bombers launching missiles at targets inside of Ukraine.\n\nStrikes on civilian infrastructure are still forbidden, as are the use of long-range missiles to strike deep inside of Russia, according to Politico.\n\nThe National Security Council, the division of the White House that normally fields questions on matters of national security, did not immediately return a request for comment on the report. But Pentagon spokesperson Sabrina Singh said \"there's been no change in our policy,\" emphasizing that US security aid is to be used within Ukraine.\n\n\"We don't encourage attacks or enable attacks inside of Russia. {"uri": "8154777318", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "08:58:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T08:58:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T08:57:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/world/story/russia-ukraine-war-joe-biden-united-states-weapons-vladimir-putin-volodymyr-zelenskyy-kharkiv-2546209-2024-05-31", "title": "Biden allows Ukraine to use US weapons to strike on Russian territory: Officials", "body": "U.S. policy calling on Ukraine not to use long range weapons against Russia has not changed\n\nPresident Joe Biden has given Ukraine the go-ahead to use American weaponry to strike inside Russia for the limited purpose of defending Kharkiv, according to four U.S. officials familiar with the matter.\n\nThe officials, who requested anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, underscored that the U.S. policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.\n\nBiden's directive allows for U.S.-supplied weapons to be used for \"counterfire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" one official said.\n\nUkrainian officials have stepped up calls on the U.S. administration to allow their forces to defend themselves against attacks originating from Russian territory. Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city, is just 20 kilometers (12 miles) from the Russian border.\n\nBiden's decision was first reported by Politico.\n\nUkrainian officials, most notably Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, have been increasingly vocal in arguing that the restriction was putting Ukrainian forces in an untenable situation as Russia intensified attacks around the northeast Kharkiv region.\n\nThe advances came with Russia exploiting a lengthy delay in replenishment of U.S. military aid and as Western Europe's inadequate military production has slowed crucial deliveries to the battlefield for Ukraine.\n\nTalks about changing the policy intensified inside the Biden administration more than two weeks ago, after Russia stepped up its offensive around Kharkiv, according to one of the officials familiar with the White House deliberations.\n\nDefense Secretary Lloyd Austin, White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan and Gen. CQ Brown, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, held a secure video conference with their Ukrainian counterparts in which the Ukrainian side pressed for permission to use U.S. weaponry to hit Russian positions across the border that were being used to attack the Kharkiv region, according to a U.S. official familiar with the White House deliberation.\n\nFollowing that May 13 meeting with the Ukrainians, Sullivan, Austin and Brown huddled and agree to make a recommendation to Biden to alter the policy.\n\nSullivan presented the recommendation to Biden two days later, making the case that it was common-sense for the Ukrainians to be able to strike back to counter the attacks on their land that were originating from Russian territory. Biden agreed.\n\nLater on May 15, Biden had a follow-up conversation with Gen. Christopher Cavoli, who leads U.S. European command, Austin and Sullivan and asked them to move forward on finalizing the details to the change in policy.\n\nMeanwhile, during Secretary of State Antony Blinken's visit to Kyiv two weeks ago, Zelenskyy made his case for using American weapons to strike back at positions in Russia that were launching attacks into north and northeast Ukraine.\n\nBlinken was convinced and brought that message back to Washington, according to three U.S. officials familiar with the top U.S. diplomat's thinking.\n\nBlinken met with Biden and Sullivan on May 17, following his visit to Kyiv, and shared what he heard from Zelenskyy and made clear that he also supported giving the Ukrainians more leeway to strike back on Russia.\n\nStill, Biden remained cautious and asked for due diligence before giving final approval.\n\nSullivan convened the administration's national security leaders for a conversation the following week, and they all agreed to move forward. Sullivan received final approval from Biden several days ago, but the guidance did not go into effect until Thursday, the official said.\n\nIt wasn't an easy decision to make. Since the start of the Russian invasion in February 2022, Biden has been steadfast in his opposition to Ukraine's offensive use of American-made weaponry, concerned that the action could be seen as provocative and lead to Moscow widening the war.\n\nBlinken said in Moldova on Wednesday that U.S. policy on how Ukraine deploys American weapons is constantly evolving, hinting that Washington may alter its unwritten prohibition on Ukraine's use of them for attacks on Russian territory. On Thursday, Blinken joined NATO foreign ministers for a meeting in Prague, where during a tour of a Czech military base he saw armored vehicles that are being sent to Kyiv.\n\nAlthough U.S. officials insist there is no formal arms ban, they have long made clear that they believe the use of American weapons to attack targets inside Russia could provoke an escalatory response from Moscow, something that Russian President Vladimir Putin has promised.\n\nThat position, Blinken noted, was a \"hallmark\" of the Biden administration's stance on Ukraine to \"adapt and adjust\" as needed.\n\n\"As the conditions have changed, as the battlefield has changed, as what Russia does has changed in terms of how it's pursuing its aggression, escalation, we've adapted and adjusted, too, and I'm confident we'll continue to do that,\" Blinken said at a news conference in Moldova.\n\n\"We're always listening, we're always learning, and we're always making determinations about what's necessary to make sure that Ukraine can effectively continue to defend itself, and we'll continue to do that,\" he said.\n\nCalls for a change in policy have been mounting.\n\nEarlier this week, French President Emmanuel Macron and NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said that Western countries should not object if Ukraine needs to strike inside Russia to defend itself. Stoltenberg reaffirmed that position on Thursday.\n\n\"I believe that time has come to (re)consider some of these restrictions to enable the Ukrainians to really defend themselves,\" he said. \"We need to remember what it is. This is a war of aggression launched by choice by Moscow against Ukraine.\"\n\nThe right to self-defense, he said, \" includes also striking legitimate military targets outside Ukraine.\"\n\nCzech Foreign Minister Jan Lipavsky said at a NATO-related event Thursday in Prague that Ukraine needs resources to counter Russia's relentless assault.\n\n\"Ukraine cannot fight against Russia with one hand tied behind its back,\" he said. \"Ukraine must be able to fight against Russia's barbaric invasion even on Russian territory. Political resolve must be backed by credible capabilities.\"\n\nNorway's foreign minister, Espen Barth Eide, told Norwegian broadcaster NRK that his country believes Ukraine \"has a crystal-clear right under international law to attack Russia inside Russia as part of the defense of its territory.\"\n\nBiden's decision comes as he's set to travel to France early next month to attend D-Day 80th anniversary commemorations in Normandy, a watershed moment in changing the course of World War II. Zelenskyy is among dozens of world leaders expected to attend the D-Day commemorations.", "source": {"uri": "indiatoday.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "India Today"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8154124364", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-30", "time": "22:35:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-30T22:35:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T22:35:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/biden-allows-ukraine-limited-use-of-us-arms-to-strike-inside-russia-say-us-officials/article_ae64b2cb-2deb-5fa0-81c3-a65260a4baf9.html", "title": "Biden allows Ukraine limited use of US arms to strike inside Russia, say US officials", "body": "By Steve Holland, Humeyra Pamuk and Phil Stewart\n\nWASHINGTON/PRAGUE (Reuters) -President Joe Biden quietly has authorized Kyiv to launch U.S.-supplied weapons at military targets inside Russia that are supporting an offensive against the northeastern Ukrainian city of Kharkiv, three U.S. officials said on Thursday.\n\nThe decision marks a policy shift by Biden, who had steadfastly refused to allow Ukraine to use American weaponry for strikes inside Russia.\n\nRussia's embassy in Washington and Russia's mission to the United Nations in New York did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nThe U.S. officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Biden's decision applies only to targets inside Russia near the border with the Kharkiv region, where an offensive launched by Moscow on May 10 has overrun some villages.\n\n\"The President recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use U.S.-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" said one U.S. official.\n\nRussia is building up forces near the northern part of the region, but it lacks the troop numbers to stage a major push, Ukraine's top commander said on Thursday.\n\nKharkiv, Ukraine's second largest city, is 19 miles (30 km) from the border with Russia.\n\nIt is the second time this year that Biden has quietly relaxed his policy on weapons supplies for Ukraine, bending to calls to send long-range missiles known as ATACMS to Kyiv.\n\nThe U.S. is the biggest supplier of weapons to Ukraine in its battle against the full-scale invasion launched by Russian President Vladimir Putin in February 2022.\n\nThe officials said that U.S. policy would continue to prohibit the Ukrainian military from using ATACMS, which have a range of up to 186 miles (300 km), and other long-range U.S.-supplied weapons for deep strikes inside Russia.\n\nNor does Biden's decision mean the U.S. now approves of drone attacks that Ukraine has been launching against Russian petroleum facilities, they said.\n\nSome NATO allies and U.S. lawmakers have been calling on Biden to relax the restriction on U.S. weapons to allow Ukraine to strike missile launchers and other military sites inside Russia that are backing Moscow's drive toward Kharkiv.\n\nRussia jetfighters flying inside Russia out of reach of Ukrainian air defenses have been supporting the offensive by loosing highly precise glide bombs at Ukrainian defense lines and into Kharkiv, where they have caused numerous civilian casualties.\n\nPutin on Tuesday warned NATO members against allowing Ukraine to fire their weapons into Russia and he raised anew a risk of nuclear war.\n\nSome experts dismissed his remarks as bluster. They noted that Putin has failed to act on similar threats in the past and already has committed the bulk of his conventional forces to Europe's biggest land war since World War II.\n\n\"I don't think we can or should be bullied by Vladimir Putin,\" said U.S. Representative Gerry Connolly, a Democratic member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. \"Is he really willing to risk nuclear war and a conflict with NATO?\"\n\nConnolly co-signed a May 20 letter with Representative Michael Turner, the Republican chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, and other lawmakers urging the administration to allow Ukraine to use U.S. weapons to hit strategic targets inside Russia.\n\nFor some time, critics have urged NATO allies to relax restrictions on use of their weapons against military targets inside Russia. Those voices have grown within the alliance since Russia launched the Kharkiv offensive.\n\nCountries that have called for relaxing restrictions or done so for their own arms sent to Ukraine include Britain, the Netherlands, Sweden, the Baltic states, Finland, Denmark, Germany and France.\n\nBiden faced the potentially embarrassing prospect that as he hosts a NATO summit in July, Russian forces would be advancing on Kharkiv and in Ukraine's east as the alliance marks its 75th anniversary, analysts said.\n\n(Reporting by Steve Holland, Humeyra Pamuk and Phil Stewart; additional reporting by Michelle Nichols in New York; writing by Jonathan Landay; editing by Jonathan Oatis and David Gregorio)\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. Success! Thank you for subscribing to our newsletter. View all of our newsletters. {"uri": "2024-05-374367190", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "10:54:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T10:54:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T10:54:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://jakartaglobe.id/news/berlin-lets-ukraine-use-german-weapons-against-targets-in-russia", "title": "Berlin Lets Ukraine Use German Weapons Against Targets In Russia", "body": "Kyiv. The German government said Friday that Ukraine can use German-supplied weapons against Russian attacks from positions just over their joint border, in a significant policy change that came a day after US President Joe Biden gave Kyiv a green light to strike back with American weapons at Russian military assets targeting the country's second-largest city.\n\nA German government statement noted that, in recent weeks, Russia has prepared, coordinated and carried out attacks on Ukraine's northeastern Kharkiv region in particular from areas just over the border in Russia.\n\n\"Together we are convinced that Ukraine has the right under international law to defend itself against these attacks,\" the statement said. \"For this, it can also use the weapons delivered for that purpose in accordance with its international legal commitments, including the ones delivered by us,\" it added, without elaborating on what Berlin called confidential agreements with Kyiv.\n\nA Russian onslaught this month in the northeastern Kharkiv region, including a Russian aerial bomb attack on a large construction supplies store that killed 18 people on May 25, has forced the evacuation of thousands of people and has stretched Ukraine's depleted forces in what is proving to be a critical period in the war, which is now in its third year. That appears to have prompted the change in policy among Western leaders.\n\nThe Kremlin's bigger and better-equipped army is exploiting Ukrainian shortages in troops and ammunition after a lengthy delay in US military aid. Western Europe's inadequate military production has also slowed crucial deliveries of military aid to Ukraine.\n\nBiden's decision allows for US-supplied weapons to be used for \"counterfire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" one Washington official told The Associated Press.\n\nBut the officials, who requested anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, stressed that the US policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.\n\nThe German announcement came hours after Russian ballistic missiles slammed into an apartment block in Kharkiv and killed at least four people in a nighttime attack.\n\nRussia launched five S-300/S-400 ballistic missiles at Kharkiv overnight, Ukraine's air force said. One of them struck a residential building close to midnight and was followed by another missile 25 minutes later that hit first responders, according to regional Gov. Oleh Syniehubov. At least 25 people were injured, he said.\n\nUkrainian officials have previously accused Russia of targeting rescue workers by hitting residential buildings with two consecutive missiles -- the first one to draw emergency crews to the scene and the second one to wound or kill them. The tactic is called a \"double tap\" in military jargon. Russia used the same method in Syria's civil war.\n\nApart from Kharkiv, Moscow's troops are pressing in the Donetsk region further south and are assembling a force for an expected attack in the Sumy region further north, according to Ukrainian officials.\n\nThe restrictions until now on the use of Western weapons have frustrated Ukrainian officials as the military has been unable to order hits on Russian troops massing across the border -- Kharkiv city is only 20 kilometers (12 miles) from Russia -- or Russian bases used to launch missile attacks.\n\nThe question of whether to allow Ukraine to hit targets on Russian soil with Western-supplied weaponry has been a delicate issue since Moscow launched its full-scale invasion on Feb. 24, 2022.\n\nWestern leaders hesitated to take the step because it runs the risk of provoking Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has repeatedly warned that the West's direct involvement could put the world on a path to nuclear conflict.\n\nBut as Russia has recently gained the battlefield initiative in some parts of the 1,000-kilometer (600-mile) front line, some Western leaders are pushing for a policy change allowing Kyiv to strike military bases inside Russia with sophisticated long-range weapons provided by its Western partners. "Deadly strikes on Kharkiv as Biden lets Ukraine use US arms inside Russia", "body": "KYIV, Ukraine: Russian strikes killed three people in the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv, the regional governor said early Friday, hours after the United States authorised Kyiv to use American weapons to hit targets inside Russia in defence of the embattled region.\n\nWith Russia having retaken the battlefield initiative in recent months, Ukraine had doubled down on calls to permit it to use longer-range US weapons to attack Russian territory -- something Washington had resisted over fears it could drag NATO into direct conflict with Moscow.\n\nBut that calculus appears to have changed since Russian forces launched a fresh offensive in the Kharkiv region this month.\n\nA Russian missile strike in Kharkiv city killed three people and wounded at least 16 others, regional Governor Oleg Synegubov said in a post on Telegram early Friday morning, noting an emergency medic was among the wounded and an ambulance was damaged.\n\n\"The enemy again used a double strike tactic, while medics, rescuers and law enforcement officers were already working on the spot,\" Synegubov said.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox\n\nSign up for The Manila Times newsletters\n\nBy signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nKharkiv Mayor Igor Terekhov said in an interview with local media there could be more people trapped under the rubble of the residential building, adding: \"There was not a single military person, not a single military object\" present.\n\nTerekhov later put the number of wounded at 23.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nKharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city, is located just across the border from Russia's Belgorod and regularly comes under attack from Russian missiles.\n\nRussian strikes that hit a hardware superstore in the city last weekend killed 16 people.\n\nRestrictions lifted\n\nUS officials said Thursday that President Joe Biden had lifted restrictions on Ukraine using weapons supplied by the United States against targets on Russian territory, but only to defend the Kharkiv region.\n\n\"The president recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use US-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" a US official said on condition of anonymity.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nA second US official confirmed the change of policy.\n\nUS Secretary of State Antony Blinken had hinted on Wednesday that Biden could change course.\n\nBlinken, who visited Ukraine earlier this month, said the United States had \"adapted and adjusted\" as the \"battlefield has changed\" in remarks to reporters in Moldova on the eve of NATO talks in Prague.\n\nAhead of the NATO meeting, alliance chief Jens Stoltenberg had also said repeatedly that it was time for members to reconsider the limits on strikes inside Russia.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron appeared to shift the dial forward on Tuesday when he said Ukraine should be allowed to \"neutralise\" bases in Russia used to launch strikes.\n\nGerman Chancellor Olaf Scholz, however, remained less sure, saying Ukraine should act within the law -- and Berlin had not supplied weapons that could hit Russia anyway.\n\nGerman did, however, promise Ukraine a new package of military aid worth 500 million euros ($540 million) on Thursday, with the defence ministry saying it included \"artillery, air defence (and) drones\".\n\nThe Kremlin, for its part, accused the West on Thursday of \"entering a new round of escalations in tensions\" in recent days.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"They are provoking Ukraine in every possible way into continuing this senseless war,\" spokesman Dmitry Peskov told reporters during a daily briefing.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8155018256", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "11:28:30", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T11:28:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T11:27:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.hurriyetdailynews.com/nato-allies-support-grows-for-ukrainian-strikes-in-russia-194158", "title": "NATO allies' support grows for Ukrainian strikes in Russia - World News", "body": "Support grew among NATO allies on Friday for using Western-donated weapons to strike inside Russian territory, while NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg downplayed Kremlin warnings of an escalation.\n\nGermany said it had given Ukraine permission to fire German-delivered weapons at targets in Russia, a day after U.S. officials said Washington had partially lifted similar restrictions to allow Ukraine to defend its eastern Kharkiv region, which borders Russia.\n\nKiev has the \"right under international law to defend itself\" against attacks coming from inside Russia, close to the border with Ukraine, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz's spokesman Steffen Hebestreit said.\n\n\"To this end, it can also use the weapons supplied for this purpose... including those supplied by us,\" he said.\n\nWashington had previously resisted allowing Ukraine to use longer-range U.S. weapons to attack Russian territory, fearing it could drag NATO into a direct conflict with Russia.\n\nThe Kremlin accused the West on Thursday of \"entering a new round of escalations in tensions\".\n\nBut NATO secretary general Jens Stoltenberg, speaking to reporters at a meeting of alliance foreign ministers in Prague, responded: \"This is part of efforts by President [Vladimir] Putin and Moscow to prevent NATO allies from supporting Ukraine to defend themselves.\"\n\n\"Ukraine has the right for self defense and we have the right to help Ukraine,\" he said.\n\nSome NATO member states are opposed, however.\n\nItalian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani said that \"for Italy, it is impossible to use our weapons outside of Ukraine\".\n\n\"We are not fighting against Russia. We're defending Ukraine and it is not the same,\" he said.\n\n'Stop the madness'\n\nA U.S. official said on Thursday that President Joe Biden \"had recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use U.S.-supplied weapons or counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them\".\n\nThe official said that ATACMS missiles, which could hit deeper inside Russia, were still prohibited.\n\nA second U.S. official confirmed the change of policy, which followed weeks of behind-the-scenes discussions between the White House and top U.S. military and State Department officials.\n\nBiden gave the final sign-off in recent days but the decision was kept secret for operational reasons and only became effective on Thursday.\n\nThe change in Washington's thinking was attributed by U.S. officials to Russia's daily pounding of Kharkiv, Ukraine's second biggest city.\n\nIn the latest Russian strikes on the city overnight, five people were killed and 23 wounded, including two children, officials said, warning residents could still be trapped under the rubble.\n\n\"The rescue and search operation continues. All services are working at the scene,\" said regional governor Oleg Synegubov.\n\nKharkiv Mayor Igor Terekhov said there had not been \"a single military person, not a single military object\" present.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has pressed Western allies for more air defense fire power.\n\n\"Our top priorities are to ensure more air defense systems for Ukraine, joint defense industry projects, and weapons for our warriors, as well as global efforts to force Russia to make peace,\" he said on social media during a visit to Sweden on Friday.\n\n\"Only together we can stop the madness from Moscow,\" he told a press conference in Stockholm.\n\n'The advance is underway'\n\nUkraine has intensified strikes on Russian targets in recent months, claiming drone attacks on military and energy infrastructure targets deep inside the country.\n\nRussia's military said on Friday that it had shot down 29 Ukrainian drones overnight that were targeting the port city of Novorossiisk and an oil depot in Temryuk.\n\nThe Temryuk strike sparked a fire, which raged for several hours before being extinguished, and wounded several oil depot workers, Krasnodar Region Governor Venyamin Kondratyev wrote on the Telegram social media channel.\n\nNo injuries were reported in the Novorossiisk strike, local authorities said.\n\nThe increasing intensity of strikes has come as Russian troops have made gradual advances in Ukraine this year after holding off a Ukrainian counter-offensive last year.\n\nRussian Defense Minister Andrei Belousov said Moscow's forces had seized 880 square kilometers (340 square miles) of territory so far in 2024.\n\n\"The advance is underway in all tactical directions,\" he said at a meeting of the Russian-led CSTO security alliance {"uri": "8154505289", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "05:44:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T05:44:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T05:43:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20240531/p2g/00m/0in/034000c", "title": "Biden partially lifts ban on Ukraine using US arms in strikes on Russian territory, US officials say", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Joe Biden has given Ukraine the go-ahead to use American weaponry to strike inside Russia for the limited purpose of defending Kharkiv, according to four U.S. officials familiar with the matter.\n\nThe officials, who requested anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, underscored that the U.S. policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.\n\nBiden's directive allows for U.S.-supplied weapons to be used for \"counterfire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" one official said.\n\nUkrainian officials have stepped up calls on the U.S. administration to allow their forces to defend themselves against attacks originating from Russian territory. Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city, is just 20 kilometers (12 miles) from the Russian border.\n\nBiden's decision was first reported by Politico.\n\nUkrainian officials, most notably Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, have been increasingly vocal in arguing that the restriction was putting Ukrainian forces in an untenable situation as Russia intensified attacks around the northeast Kharkiv region.\n\nThe advances came with Russia exploiting a lengthy delay in replenishment of U.S. military aid and as Western Europe's inadequate military production has slowed crucial deliveries to the battlefield for Ukraine.\n\nTalks about changing the policy intensified inside the Biden administration more than two weeks ago, after Russia stepped up its offensive around Kharkiv, according to one of the officials familiar with the White House deliberations.\n\nDefense Secretary Lloyd Austin, White House national security adviser Jake Sullivan and Gen. CQ Brown, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, held a secure video conference with their Ukrainian counterparts in which the Ukrainian side pressed for permission to use U.S. weaponry to hit Russian positions across the border that were being used to attack the Kharkiv region, according to a U.S. official familiar with the White House deliberation.\n\nFollowing that May 13 meeting with the Ukrainians, Sullivan, Austin and Brown huddled and agree to make a recommendation to Biden to alter the policy.\n\nSullivan presented the recommendation to Biden two days later, making the case that it was common-sense for the Ukrainians to be able to strike back to counter the attacks on their land that were originating from Russian territory. Biden agreed.\n\nLater on May 15, Biden had a follow-up conversation with Gen. Christopher Cavoli, who leads U.S. European command, Austin and Sullivan and asked them to move forward on finalizing the details to the change in policy.\n\nMeanwhile, during Secretary of State Antony Blinken's visit to Kyiv two weeks ago, Zelenskyy made his case for using American weapons to strike back at positions in Russia that were launching attacks into north and northeast Ukraine.\n\nBlinken was convinced and brought that message back to Washington, according to three U.S. officials familiar with the top U.S. diplomat's thinking.\n\nBlinken met with Biden and Sullivan on May 17, following his visit to Kyiv, and shared what he heard from Zelenskyy and made clear that he also supported giving the Ukrainians more leeway to strike back on Russia.\n\nStill, Biden remained cautious and asked for due diligence before giving final approval.\n\nSullivan convened the administration's national security leaders for a conversation the following week, and they all agreed to move forward. Sullivan received final approval from Biden several days ago, but the guidance did not go into effect until Thursday, the official said.\n\nIt wasn't an easy decision to make. Since the start of the Russian invasion in February 2022, Biden has been steadfast in his opposition to Ukraine's offensive use of American-made weaponry, concerned that the action could be seen as provocative and lead to Moscow widening the war.\n\nBlinken said in Moldova on Wednesday that U.S. policy on how Ukraine deploys American weapons is constantly evolving, hinting that Washington may alter its unwritten prohibition on Ukraine's use of them for attacks on Russian territory. On Thursday, Blinken joined NATO foreign ministers for a meeting in Prague, where during a tour of a Czech military base he saw armored vehicles that are being sent to Kyiv.\n\nAlthough U.S. officials insist there is no formal arms ban, they have long made clear that they believe the use of American weapons to attack targets inside Russia could provoke an escalatory response from Moscow, something that Russian President Vladimir Putin has promised.\n\nThat position, Blinken noted, was a \"hallmark\" of the Biden administration's stance on Ukraine to \"adapt and adjust\" as needed.\n\n\"As the conditions have changed, as the battlefield has changed, as what Russia does has changed in terms of how it's pursuing its aggression, escalation, we've adapted and adjusted, too, and I'm confident we'll continue to do that,\" Blinken said at a news conference in Moldova.\n\n\"We're always listening, we're always learning, and we're always making determinations about what's necessary to make sure that Ukraine can effectively continue to defend itself, and we'll continue to do that,\" he said.\n\nCalls for a change in policy have been mounting.\n\nEarlier this week, French President Emmanuel Macron and NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said that Western countries should not object if Ukraine needs to strike inside Russia to defend itself. Stoltenberg reaffirmed that position on Thursday.\n\n\"I believe that time has come to (re)consider some of these restrictions to enable the Ukrainians to really defend themselves,\" he said. \"We need to remember what it is. This is a war of aggression launched by choice by Moscow against Ukraine.\"\n\nThe right to self-defense, he said, \" includes also striking legitimate military targets outside Ukraine.\"\n\nCzech Foreign Minister Jan Lipavsky said at a NATO-related event Thursday in Prague that Ukraine needs resources to counter Russia's relentless assault.\n\n\"Ukraine cannot fight against Russia with one hand tied behind its back,\" he said. \"Ukraine must be able to fight against Russia's barbaric invasion even on Russian territory. Political resolve must be backed by credible capabilities.\"\n\nNorway's foreign minister, Espen Barth Eide, told Norwegian broadcaster NRK that his country believes Ukraine \"has a crystal-clear right under international law to attack Russia inside Russia as part of the defense of its territory.\"\n\nBiden's decision comes as he's set to travel to France early next month to attend D-Day 80th anniversary commemorations in Normandy, a watershed moment in changing the course of World War II. Zelenskyy is among dozens of world leaders expected to attend the D-Day commemorations.", "source": {"uri": "mainichi.jp", "dataType": "news", "title": "\u6bce\u65e5\u65b0\u805e"}, "authors": [], "title": "Deadly strikes on Kharkiv as Biden lets Ukraine use US arms inside Russia", "body": "Two Ukrainian servicemen sit facing the 'Wall of Remembrance of the Fallen for Ukraine', a memorial for Ukrainian soldiers, in the center of Kyiv\n\nRussian strikes killed three people in the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv, the regional governor said early Friday, hours after the United States authorised Kyiv to use American weapons to hit targets inside Russia in defence of the embattled region.\n\nWith Russia having retaken the battlefield initiative in recent months, Ukraine had doubled down on calls to permit it to use longer-range US weapons to attack Russian territory -- something Washington had resisted over fears it could drag NATO into direct conflict with Moscow.\n\nBut that calculus appears to have changed since Russian forces launched a fresh offensive in the Kharkiv region this month.\n\nA Russian missile strike in Kharkiv city killed three people and wounded at least 16 others, regional Governor Oleg Synegubov said in a post on Telegram early Friday morning, noting an emergency medic was among the wounded and an ambulance was damaged.\n\n\"The enemy again used a double strike tactic, while medics, rescuers and law enforcement officers were already working on the spot,\" Synegubov said.\n\nKharkiv Mayor Igor Terekhov said in an interview with local media there could be more people trapped under the rubble of the residential building, adding: \"There was not a single military person, not a single military object\" present.\n\nTerekhov later put the number of wounded at 23.\n\nKharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city, is located just across the border from Russia's Belgorod and regularly comes under attack from Russian missiles.\n\nRussian strikes that hit a hardware superstore in the city last weekend killed 16 people.\n\n- Restrictions lifted -\n\nUS officials said Thursday that President Joe Biden had lifted restrictions on Ukraine using weapons supplied by the United States against targets on Russian territory, but only to defend the Kharkiv region.\n\nMore from this section Djokovic shrugs off troubles in winning start at French Open Hundreds attend national conference in St. John's to see latest tech for the bottom of bodies of water Kate branded the Royal Family's 'greatest asset' as future Queen 'seen out and about'\n\n\"The president recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use US-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" a US official said on condition of anonymity.\n\nA second US official confirmed the change of policy.\n\nUS Secretary of State Antony Blinken had hinted on Wednesday that Biden could change course.\n\nBlinken, who visited Ukraine earlier this month, said the United States had \"adapted and adjusted\" as the \"battlefield has changed\" in remarks to reporters in Moldova on the eve of NATO talks in Prague.\n\nAhead of the NATO meeting, alliance chief Jens Stoltenberg had also said repeatedly that it was time for members to reconsider the limits on strikes inside Russia.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron appeared to shift the dial forward on Tuesday when he said Ukraine should be allowed to \"neutralise\" bases in Russia used to launch strikes.\n\nGerman Chancellor Olaf Scholz, however, remained less sure, saying Ukraine should act within the law -- and Berlin had not supplied weapons that could hit Russia anyway.\n\nGerman did, however, promise Ukraine a new package of military aid worth 500 million euros ($540 million) on Thursday, with the defence ministry saying it included \"artillery, air defence (and) drones\".\n\nThe Kremlin, for its part, accused the West on Thursday of \"entering a new round of escalations in tensions\" in recent days.\n\n\"They are provoking Ukraine in every possible way into continuing this senseless war,\" spokesman Dmitry Peskov told reporters during a daily briefing.\n\nbur-juf/smw/cwl", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.news.com.au/breaking-news/deadly-strikes-on-kharkiv-as-biden-lets-ukraine-use-us-arms-inside-russia/news-story/2057fc65198c84bbef93f943046d8306", "title": "NATO allies' support grows for Ukrainian strikes in Russia", "body": "Support grew among NATO allies on Friday for using Western-donated weapons to strike inside Russian territory, while NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg downplayed Kremlin warnings of an escalation.\n\nGermany said it had given Ukraine permission to fire German-delivered weapons at targets in Russia, a day after US officials said Washington had partially lifted similar restrictions to allow Ukraine to defend its eastern Kharkiv region, which borders Russia.\n\nKyiv has the \"right under international law to defend itself\" against attacks coming from inside Russia, close to the border with Ukraine, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz's spokesman Steffen Hebestreit said.\n\n\"To this end, it can also use the weapons supplied for this purpose... including those supplied by us,\" he said.\n\nWashington had previously resisted allowing Ukraine to use longer-range US weapons to attack Russian territory, fearing it could drag NATO into a direct conflict with Russia.\n\nThe Kremlin accused the West on Thursday of \"entering a new round of escalations in tensions\".\n\nBut NATO secretary general Jens Stoltenberg, speaking to reporters at a meeting of alliance foreign ministers in Prague, responded: \"This is part of efforts by President (Vladimir) Putin and Moscow to prevent NATO allies from supporting Ukraine to defend themselves.\"\n\n\"Ukraine has the right for self defence and we have the right to help Ukraine,\" he said.\n\nSome NATO member states are opposed, however.\n\nItalian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani said that \"for Italy, it is impossible to use our weapons outside of Ukraine\".\n\n\"We are not fighting against Russia. We're defending Ukraine and it is not the same,\" he said.\n\n- 'Stop the madness' -\n\nA US official said on Thursday that President Joe Biden \"had recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use US-supplied weapons or counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them\".\n\nThe official said that ATACMS missiles, which could hit deeper inside Russia, were still prohibited.\n\nA second US official confirmed the change of policy, which followed weeks of behind-the-scenes discussions between the White House and top US military and State Department officials.\n\nBiden gave the final sign-off in recent days but the decision was kept secret for operational reasons and only became effective on Thursday.\n\nThe change in Washington's thinking was attributed by US officials to Russia's daily pounding of Kharkiv, Ukraine's second biggest city.\n\nIn the latest Russian strikes on the city overnight, five people were killed and 23 wounded, including two children, officials said, warning residents could still be trapped under the rubble.\n\n\"The rescue and search operation continues. All services are working at the scene,\" said regional governor Oleg Synegubov.\n\nKharkiv Mayor Igor Terekhov said there had not been \"a single military person, not a single military object\" present.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has pressed Western allies for more air defence fire power.\n\n\"Our top priorities are to ensure more air defence systems for Ukraine, joint defence industry projects, and weapons for our warriors, as well as global efforts to force Russia to make peace,\" he said on social media during a visit to Sweden on Friday.\n\n\"Only together we can stop the madness from Moscow,\" he told a press conference in Stockholm.\n\n- 'The advance is underway' -\n\nUkraine has intensified strikes on Russian targets in recent months, claiming drone attacks on military and energy infrastructure targets deep inside the country.\n\nRussia's military said on Friday that it had shot down 29 Ukrainian drones overnight that were targeting the port city of Novorossiisk and an oil depot in Temryuk.\n\nThe Temryuk strike sparked a fire, which raged for several hours before being extinguished, and wounded several oil depot workers, Krasnodar Region Governor Venyamin Kondratyev wrote on the Telegram social media channel.\n\nNo injuries were reported in the Novorossiisk strike, local authorities said.\n\nThe increasing intensity of strikes has come as Russian troops have made gradual advances in Ukraine this year after holding off a Ukrainian counter-offensive last year.\n\nRussian Defence Minister Andrei Belousov said Moscow's forces had seized 880 square kilometres (340 square miles) of territory so far in 2024.\n\n\"The advance is underway in all tactical directions,\" he said at a meeting of the Russian-led CSTO security alliance {"uri": "8154446084", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "04:54:02", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T04:54:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T04:53:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://timesofmalta.com/article/biden-lets-ukraine-use-us-arms-inside-russia.1093250", "title": "Biden lets Ukraine use US arms inside Russia", "body": "US President Joe Biden secretly lifted restrictions on Ukraine using American-supplied weapons against targets on Russian territory, but only to defend the under-fire Kharkiv region, US officials said Thursday.\n\nBiden had come under increasing pressure from a desperate Ukraine to ease his ban, but had so far resisted amid fears it could drag NATO into direct conflict or even a nuclear standoff with Moscow.\n\n\"The president recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use US-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" a US official said.\n\n\"Our policy with respect to prohibiting the use of ATACMS or long-range strikes inside of Russia has not changed,\" the official said on condition of anonymity, referring to long-range missiles recently sent by Washington to Kyiv.\n\nA second US official confirmed Biden's change of policy, which comes as Russian forces push forward with an offensive against the northeastern Kharkiv region.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has been pressing Kyiv's supporters - chiefly the United States - to allow it to use the longer-range weaponry they supply to hit targets on Russian soil.\n\nThe United States has been rushing to get arms to Ukraine after Congress passed a huge military aid package following a six-month delay in April, but Biden had been reluctant to allow cross-border strikes.\n\nHowever, US Secretary of State Antony Blinken had hinted on Wednesday that Biden was changing course in response, saying that Washington had \"adapted and adjusted.\"\n\nBiden's shift followed weeks of behind-the-scenes discussions between the White House and top US military and State Department officials in the days after Russia launched its Kharkiv offensive on May 10.\n\nUkraine asked for permission to use US arms on Russian territory on May 13, and Biden agreed in principle on May 15 after National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan made the case for Ukraine to be able to defend itself.\n\nBiden then met on May 17 with Blinken, who travelled to Kyiv earlier this month to see the increasingly grave situation as Russia pushes towards Kharkiv, and had been widely reported to be pressing Biden to ease the rules.\n\nAfter working through the details, the US president gave a final sign-off in recent days but the decision was kept secret for operational reasons and only became effective on Thursday.\n\nThe White House has however made it clear to Kyiv that the permission for cross-border attacks was limited to targets just over the border, which were being used by Russia to launch offensives.\n\nOfficials also insisted that they had been expecting some form of Russian offensive and that with the influx of US arms, it has been stalled, preventing the possible capture of Kharkiv city.\n\nPressure had been mounting for Biden and other Western countries to end their ban on Ukraine using their weapons to strike Russian soil.\n\nAhead of a meeting of NATO foreign ministers in Prague, alliance chief Jens Stoltenberg said repeatedly it was time for members to reconsider those limits.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron also appeared to shift the dial forward on Tuesday when he said Ukraine should be allowed to \"neutralize\" bases in Russia used to launch strikes.\n\nSome countries including Britain and the Netherlands had already said Kyiv has the right to use their weapons to strike military targets in Russia.\n\nBiden's change also comes shortly before he heads to Europe for a series of meetings where Kyiv's plight will be in focus.\n\nBiden will attend ceremonies in France marking the World War II D-Day landings in early June where Ukraine's Zelensky will also be present.\n\nThe US president will also meet leaders of the world's top economies at the G7 summit in Italy.\n\nBut Zelensky has criticized Biden for apparently planning to skip a Ukraine peace summit in Switzerland just after the G7, which clashes with an election fundraiser for the US president hosted by Hollywood stars George Clooney and Julia Roberts.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-373857478", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "00:25:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T00:25:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T00:25:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.europesun.com/news/274390570/biden-partially-lifts-ban-on-ukraine-using-us-arms-in-strikes-on-russian-territory-us-officials-say", "title": "Biden partially lifts ban on Ukraine using US arms in strikes on Russian territory, US officials say", "body": "The officials, who requested anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, underscored that the U.S. policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.\n\nBiden's directive allows for U.S.-supplied weapons to be used for \"counterfire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" one official said.\n\nThe move comes as Ukrainian officials have stepped up calls on the U.S. administration to allow its forces to defend itself against attacks originating from Russian territory. Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city, is just 20 kilometers (12 miles) from the Russian border.\n\nBiden's decision was first reported by Politico.\n\nUkrainian officials, most notably Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, have been increasingly vocal in arguing that the restriction was putting Ukrainian forces in an untenable situation as Russia intensified attacks around the northeast Kharkiv region.\n\nThe advances came with Russia exploiting a lengthy delay in replenishment of U.S. military aid and as Western Europe's inadequate military production has slowed crucial deliveries to the battlefield for Ukraine.\n\nDuring Secretary of State Antony Blinken's visit to Kyiv two weeks ago, Zelenskyy made his case for using American weapons to strike back at positions in Russia that were launching attacks into north and northeast Ukraine, according to three U.S. officials who spoke on condition of anonymity to discuss internal administration deliberations.\n\nBlinken was convinced and brought that message back to Washington, but it was ultimately Biden's decision to make, the officials said.\n\nSince the start of the Russian invasion in February 2022, Biden has been steadfast in his opposition to Ukraine's offensive use of American-made weaponry, concerned that the action could be seen as provocative and lead to Moscow widening the war.\n\nBlinken said in Moldova on Wednesday that U.S. policy on how Ukraine deploys American weapons is constantly evolving, hinting that Washington may alter its unwritten prohibition on Ukraine's use of them for attacks on Russian territory. On Thursday, Blinken joined NATO foreign ministers for a meeting in Prague, where during a tour of a Czech military base he saw armored vehicles that are being sent to Kyiv.\n\nAlthough U.S. officials insist there is no formal arms ban, they have long made clear that they believe the use of American weapons to attack targets inside Russia could provoke an escalatory response from Moscow, something that Russian President Vladimir Putin has promised.\n\nThat position, Blinken noted, was a \"hallmark\" of the Biden administration's stance on Ukraine to \"adapt and adjust\" as needed. Blinken visited Kyiv earlier this month and heard a direct appeal from Zelenskyy to use U.S. military assistance to strike positions in Russian from where attacks on Ukraine are launched.\n\n\"As the conditions have changed, as the battlefield has changed, as what Russia does has changed in terms of how it's pursuing its aggression, escalation, we've adapted and adjusted too, and I'm confident we'll continue to do that,\" Blinken said at a news conference in Moldova.\n\n\"At every step along the way, we've adapted and adjusted as necessary, and so that's exactly what we'll do going forward,\" he said. \"We're always listening, we're always learning, and we're always making determinations about what's necessary to make sure that Ukraine can effectively continue to defend itself, and we'll continue to do that.\"\n\nCalls for a change in policy have been mounting.\n\nEarlier this week, French President Emmanuel Macron and NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said that Western countries should not object if Ukraine needs to strike inside Russia to defend itself. Stoltenberg reaffirmed that position on Thursday.\n\n\"I believe that time has come to (re)consider some of these restrictions to enable the Ukrainians to really defend themselves,\" he said. \"We need to remember what it is. This is a war of aggression launched by choice by Moscow against Ukraine.\"\n\nThe right to self-defense, he said, \" includes also striking legitimate military targets outside Ukraine.\"\n\nCzech Foreign Minister Jan Lipavsky said at a NATO-related event Thursday in Prague that Ukraine needs resources to counter Russia's relentless assault.\n\n\"Ukraine cannot fight against Russia with one hand tied behind its back,\" he said. \"Ukraine must be able to fight against Russia's barbaric invasion even on Russian territory. Political resolve must be backed by credible capabilities.\"\n\nNorway's foreign minister, Espen Barth Eide, told Norwegian broadcaster NRK that his country believes Ukraine \"has a crystal-clear right under international law to attack Russia inside Russia as part of the defense of its territory.\"\n\nBiden's decision comes as he's set to travel to France early next month to attend D-Day 80th anniversary commemorations in Normandy, a watershed moment in changing the course of World War II. Zelenskyy is among dozens of world leaders expected to attend to attend the D-Day commemorations.\n\n__\n\nBy MATTHEW LEE, AAMER MADHANI and ZEKE MILLER Associated Press\n\nLee reported from Prague. Associated Press writers Karel Janicek in Prague and Ellen Knickmeyer contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "europesun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "europesun.com"}, "authors": [], "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.bizpacreview.com/2024/05/31/ww-iii-watch-biden-allows-ukraine-to-strike-russia-with-u-s-weapons-1462801/", "title": "WW III watch: Biden allows Ukraine to strike Russia with U.S. weapons", "body": "The Biden administration has reportedly \"quietly\" authorized Ukraine to use U.S. weapons to strike Russian forces within Russia itself.\n\n\"The president recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use U.S. weapons for counter-fire purposes in Kharkiv so Ukraine can hit back at Russian forces hitting them or preparing to hit them,\" an anonymous official told Politico on Thursday.\n\nThis means Ukrainian forces can now use American rockets and rocket launchers to eliminate Russian missiles headed toward Kharkiv and to also take down Russian bombers dropping bombs on Kharkiv.\n\n\"But the official said Ukraine cannot use those weapons to hit civilian infrastructure or launch long-range missiles, such as the Army Tactical Missile System, to hit military targets deep inside Russia,\" Politico notes.\n\nThe official stressed that the original policy of not authorizing long-range strikes within Russia \"has not changed.\"\n\nKharkiv is a Ukrainian city that closely borders Russia.\n\nUkraine reportedly asked the Biden administration to institute this policy after Russia began attacking Kharkiv earlier this month.\n\nSecretary of State Antony Blinken previously hinted that a change in policy was incoming.\n\n\"We haven't encouraged or enabled strikes outside of Ukraine, but Ukraine, as I've said before, has to make its own decisions about the best way to effectively defend itself,\" he said during a Wednesday presser. \"We're going to make sure that it has the equipment it needs to do that.\"\n\n\"And another hallmark of our support for Ukraine over these now more than two years has been to adapt. As the conditions have changed, as the battlefield has changed, as what Russia does has changed in terms of how it's pursuing its aggression, escalation, we've adapted and adjusted too, and I'm confident we'll continue to do that,\" he added.\n\nThis position was shared after several top U.S. allies, including Germany and France, began calling for Ukraine to have the right to wage attacks inside Russia itself using Western weapons.\n\n\"Ukrainian soil is being attacked from bases in Russia,\" French President Emmanuel Macron said during a visit this Tuesday to Schloss Meseberg in Brandenburg, Germany, according to CNN.\n\n\"So how do we explain to the Ukrainians that we're going to have to protect these towns and basically everything we're seeing around Kharkiv at the moment if we tell them you are not allowed to hit the point from which the missiles are fired?\" he added.\n\n\"We think that we should allow them to neutralize the military sites from which the missiles are fired and, basically, the military sites from which Ukraine is attacked,\" he continued.\n\nTo his credit, Macron did stress that the West \"must not allow them [the Ukrainians] to hit other targets in Russia,\" including civilian homes and infrastructure.\n\n(Video Credit: Fox News)\n\nDuring the same presser, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz echoed Macron's sentiment and stressed that Ukraine is allowed to protect itself so long as it stays within the rules established by the West.\n\n\"Ukraine has every possibility under international law for what it is doing,\" he said. \"That has to be said explicitly. I find it strange when some people argue that it should not be allowed to defend itself and take measures that are suitable for this.\"\n\nWhy is any of this a concern? Because Western nations are fearful that if donated weapons are used inside Russia, it could trigger massive escalation and even another world war.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has nevertheless repeatedly tried to pressure his Western allies into loosening the rules for him.\n\n\"In a discussion with Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin on Wednesday, Ukrainian Defense Minister Rustem Umerov made a 'hard push' to use U.S. weapons in Russia,\" Politico notes.\n\nIt's known for a fact that Ukraine has used its own drones to target Russian infrastructure not directly related to the war.\n\nIn the wake of the latest news, critics are now crying foul, accusing the Biden administration of pushing America toward another World War:\n\nWe have no tolerance for comments containing violence, racism, profanity, vulgarity, doxing, or discourteous behavior. {"uri": "2024-05-373874398", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "01:04:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T01:04:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T00:58:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.sacbee.com/news/nation-world/world/article288897120.html", "title": "Under pressure, Biden allows Ukraine to use US weapons to strike inside Russia", "body": "By David E. Sanger and Edward Wong NYT News Service/Syndicate Stories\n\nPRAGUE -- President Joe Biden, under pressure from his top national security aides and European allies, has authorized Ukraine to conduct limited strikes inside Russia with U.S.-made weapons, opening what could well be a new chapter in the war for Ukraine, U.S. officials said Thursday.\n\nBiden's decision appears to mark the first time that an American president has authorized limited military attacks on artillery, missile bases and command centers inside the borders of a nuclear-armed adversary. White House officials insisted, however, that the authorization extended only to what they characterized as acts of self-defense, so that Ukraine could protect Kharkiv, its second-largest city, and the surrounding areas in the northeast from relentless fire from missiles, glide bombs and artillery shells from just over the border.\n\n\"The president recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use U.S.-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" a U.S. official said in a statement issued by the administration. \"Our policy with respect to prohibiting the use of ATACMS or long-range strikes inside of Russia has not changed,\" the statement continued, referring to an artillery system, provided to Ukraine, that has the capability to reach deep inside Russian territory.\n\nInside the White House, Biden's deliberations were closely held, known only to a very narrow group of aides. But The New York Times revealed last week that Secretary of State Antony Blinken had come back from a sobering trip to Kyiv and privately told the president that his 27-month-long ban against shooting American weapons into Russian territory was now placing parts of Ukraine in peril. The Russians, he said, were exploiting the president's ban and mounting constant attacks from a safe haven just inside the Russian border.\n\nBy that time, Jake Sullivan, the president's national security adviser, had also begun changing his view, senior officials said. So had U.S. allies: Britain weeks ago allowed Ukraine to use its Storm Shadow long-range missile systems for attacks anywhere in Russia, and France and Germany recently took the same position. So did Jens Stoltenberg, secretary-general of NATO.\n\nThe decision follows weeks of discussion with the Ukrainians after Russia began a major assault on Kharkiv.\n\nBecause Kharkiv is so close to Russia, President Volodymyr Zelenskyy of Ukraine repeatedly pressed Biden and his aides for the right to strike back inside Russia. Biden deflected those requests for months, concerned that using American weapons could escalate the conflict -- and put the United States into a direct confrontation with Russia.\n\nWhen he relented, it was in the most narrowly prescribed way. The permission from Biden is intended solely for Ukraine to strike military sites in Russia being used to attack the Kharkiv area, U.S. officials said. Attacks from Russia in other regions -- even near Kyiv, the capital -- cannot be answered with the use of American weapons.\n\nA senior U.S. official in Washington said the administration's policy prohibiting Ukraine from using U.S.-made weapons for \"long-range\" attacks inside Russia had not changed.\n\nThe decision by Biden was reported earlier Thursday by Politico.\n\nThe Pentagon is charged with giving Ukraine the exact guidelines of what it can strike in Russia, U.S. officials said. Those have already been conveyed by Secretary of Defense Lloyd J. Austin III to Gen. Christopher G. Cavoli, the four-star commander of the U.S. European Command and the supreme allied commander for Europe. It was Cavoli who conveyed the decision to Ukraine, officials said.", "source": {"uri": "sacbee.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Sacramento Bee"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-374330687", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "10:21:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T10:21:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T10:02:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/nato-allies-support-grows-for-ukrainian-strikes-in-russia/article_e3ce7be9-788a-5333-aade-da210d09ed02.html", "title": "NATO allies' support grows for Ukrainian strikes in Russia", "body": "Kharkiv officials said all the targets of overnight attacks were civilian\n\nSupport grew among NATO allies on Friday for using Western-donated weapons to strike inside Russian territory, while NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg downplayed Kremlin warnings of an escalation.\n\nGermany said it had given Ukraine permission to fire German-delivered weapons at targets in Russia, a day after US officials said Washington had partially lifted similar restrictions to allow Ukraine to defend its eastern Kharkiv region, which borders Russia.\n\nKyiv has the \"right under international law to defend itself\" against attacks coming from inside Russia, close to the border with Ukraine, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz's spokesman Steffen Hebestreit said.\n\n\"To this end, it can also use the weapons supplied for this purpose... including those supplied by us,\" he said.\n\nWashington had previously resisted allowing Ukraine to use longer-range US weapons to attack Russian territory, fearing it could drag NATO into a direct conflict with Russia.\n\nThe Kremlin accused the West on Thursday of \"entering a new round of escalations in tensions\".\n\nBut NATO secretary general Jens Stoltenberg, speaking to reporters at a meeting of alliance foreign ministers in Prague, responded: \"This is part of efforts by President (Vladimir) Putin and Moscow to prevent NATO allies from supporting Ukraine to defend themselves.\"\n\n\"Ukraine has the right for self defence and we have the right to help Ukraine,\" he said.\n\nSome NATO member states are opposed, however.\n\nItalian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani said that \"for Italy, it is impossible to use our weapons outside of Ukraine\".\n\n\"We are not fighting against Russia. We're defending Ukraine and it is not the same,\" he said.\n\n- 'Stop the madness' -\n\nA US official said on Thursday that President Joe Biden \"had recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use US-supplied weapons or counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them\".\n\nThe official said that ATACMS missiles, which could hit deeper inside Russia, were still prohibited.\n\nA second US official confirmed the change of policy, which followed weeks of behind-the-scenes discussions between the White House and top US military and State Department officials.\n\nBiden gave the final sign-off in recent days but the decision was kept secret for operational reasons and only became effective on Thursday.\n\nThe change in Washington's thinking was attributed by US officials to Russia's daily pounding of Kharkiv, Ukraine's second biggest city.\n\nIn the latest Russian strikes on the city overnight, five people were killed and 23 wounded, including two children, officials said, warning residents could still be trapped under the rubble.\n\n\"The rescue and search operation continues. All services are working at the scene,\" said regional governor Oleg Synegubov.\n\nKharkiv Mayor Igor Terekhov said there had not been \"a single military person, not a single military object\" present.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has pressed Western allies for more air defence fire power.\n\n\"Our top priorities are to ensure more air defence systems for Ukraine, joint defence industry projects, and weapons for our warriors, as well as global efforts to force Russia to make peace,\" he said on social media during a visit to Sweden on Friday.\n\n\"Only together we can stop the madness from Moscow,\" he told a press conference in Stockholm.\n\n- 'The advance is underway' -\n\nUkraine has intensified strikes on Russian targets in recent months, claiming drone attacks on military and energy infrastructure targets deep inside the country.\n\nRussia's military said on Friday that it had shot down 29 Ukrainian drones overnight that were targeting the port city of Novorossiisk and an oil depot in Temryuk.\n\nThe Temryuk strike sparked a fire, which raged for several hours before being extinguished, and wounded several oil depot workers, Krasnodar Region Governor Venyamin Kondratyev wrote on the Telegram social media channel.\n\nNo injuries were reported in the Novorossiisk strike, local authorities said.\n\nThe increasing intensity of strikes has come as Russian troops have made gradual advances in Ukraine this year after holding off a Ukrainian counter-offensive last year.\n\nRussian Defence Minister Andrei Belousov said Moscow's forces had seized 880 square kilometres (340 square miles) of territory so far in 2024.\n\n\"The advance is underway in all tactical directions,\" he said at a meeting of the Russian-led CSTO security alliance in Almaty, according to Russian news agencies.\n\nbur-dt/jbr/gil\n\nMore from this section\n\nRepublican blocks confirmation of first Native American federal judge for Montana\n\niPhone Won't Turn On or Charge? as Biden lets Ukraine use US arms inside Russia", "body": "Two Ukrainian servicemen sit facing the 'Wall of Remembrance of the Fallen for Ukraine', a memorial for Ukrainian soldiers, in the center of Kyiv\n\nRussian strikes killed three people in the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv, the regional governor said early Friday, hours after the United States authorised Kyiv to use American weapons to hit targets inside Russia in defence of the embattled region.\n\nWith Russia having retaken the battlefield initiative in recent months, Ukraine had doubled down on calls to permit it to use longer-range US weapons to attack Russian territory -- something Washington had resisted over fears it could drag NATO into direct conflict with Moscow.\n\nBut that calculus appears to have changed since Russian forces launched a fresh offensive in the Kharkiv region this month.\n\nA Russian missile strike in Kharkiv city killed three people and wounded at least 16 others, regional Governor Oleg Synegubov said in a post on Telegram early Friday morning, noting an emergency medic was among the wounded and an ambulance was damaged.\n\n\"The enemy again used a double strike tactic, while medics, rescuers and law enforcement officers were already working on the spot,\" Synegubov said.\n\nKharkiv Mayor Igor Terekhov said in an interview with local media there could be more people trapped under the rubble of the residential building, adding: \"There was not a single military person, not a single military object\" present.\n\nTerekhov later put the number of wounded at 23.\n\nKharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city, is located just across the border from Russia's Belgorod and regularly comes under attack from Russian missiles.\n\nRussian strikes that hit a hardware superstore in the city last weekend killed 16 people.\n\n- Restrictions lifted -\n\nUS officials said Thursday that President Joe Biden had lifted restrictions on Ukraine using weapons supplied by the United States against targets on Russian territory, but only to defend the Kharkiv region.\n\n\"The president recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use US-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" a US official said on condition of anonymity.\n\nA second US official confirmed the change of policy.\n\nUS Secretary of State Antony Blinken had hinted on Wednesday that Biden could change course.\n\nBlinken, who visited Ukraine earlier this month, said the United States had \"adapted and adjusted\" as the \"battlefield has changed\" in remarks to reporters in Moldova on the eve of NATO talks in Prague.\n\nAhead of the NATO meeting, alliance chief Jens Stoltenberg had also said repeatedly that it was time for members to reconsider the limits on strikes inside Russia.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron appeared to shift the dial forward on Tuesday when he said Ukraine should be allowed to \"neutralise\" bases in Russia used to launch strikes.\n\nGerman Chancellor Olaf Scholz, however, remained less sure, saying Ukraine should act within the law -- and Berlin had not supplied weapons that could hit Russia anyway.\n\nGerman did, however, promise Ukraine a new package of military aid worth 500 million euros ($540 million) on Thursday, with the defence ministry saying it included \"artillery, air defence (and) drones\".\n\nThe Kremlin, for its part, accused the West on Thursday of \"entering a new round of escalations in tensions\" in recent days.\n\n\"They are provoking Ukraine in every possible way into continuing this senseless war,\" spokesman Dmitry Peskov told reporters during a daily briefing.\n\nbur-juf/smw/cwl\n\nMore from this
