{"uri": "2024-05-374318772", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "10:11:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T10:11:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T09:47:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/ukraine-can-use-german-weapons-defend-kharkiv-border-region-berlin-says-2024-05-31/", "title": "Ukraine can use German weapons to defend Kharkiv border region, Berlin says", "body": "BERLIN, May 31 (Reuters) - Germany said on Friday Ukraine could use weapons supplied by Berlin to defend itself against attacks launched from just inside Russia against Ukraine's northern border region around the city of Kharkiv in accordance with international law.\n\nGermany has discussed with its allies Russian strikes on the Kharkiv region from positions in the immediately adjacent Russian border area, a government spokesperson said.\n\n\"We are jointly convinced that Ukraine has the right, guaranteed under international law, to defend itself against these attacks,\" the spokesperson said in a statement.\n\n\"To do so, it can also use the weapons supplied for this purpose in accordance with its international legal obligations; including those supplied by us.\"\n\nThe statement came after days of scrutiny of German Chancellor Olaf Scholz's government over whether it had changed its stance on allowing Kyiv to use German weapons to strike into Russian territory.\n\nSpeaking in Prague on Friday, NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg also spoke in favour of Ukraine using weapons provided by Western countries to strike legitimate military targets inside Russian territory.\n\nGerman officials have declined publicly to divulge specifics on how it would like Ukraine to deploy Western-supplied weapons, wary of rhetoric that could ratchet up tensions at a time when Russia is threatening tactical nuclear strikes against Ukraine.\n\nThe majority of weapons already delivered to Ukraine by Germany are not suitable for attacks on Russian positions well behind the frontline. Self-propelled howitzers, for example, can engage targets at a distance of up to 56 kilometres (35 miles), but are not deployed in the immediate vicinity of the front.\n\nFrance, Britain and the United States have supplied Ukraine with weapons with greater target ranges.\n\nBerlin's statement came a day after U.S. officials suggested President Joe Biden had quietly shifted policy to allow Kyiv to fire U.S.-supplied weapons at targets inside Russia but only near the border with the Kharkiv region.\n\nPreviously Biden had steadfastly refused to let Ukraine use American weaponry for strikes inside Russia.\n\nThe calls to allow the use of Western weapons against missile launchers and other military sites inside Russia come as Moscow is claiming territorial gains in a cross-border offensive on the region surrounding Ukraine's second biggest city.\n\nWriting by Friederike Heine and Matthias Williams, Editing by Rachel More and Gareth Jones", "source": {"uri": "reuters.com", {"uri": "2024-05-374232334", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "08:56:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T08:56:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T08:54:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/world/nato-ministers-prague-allies-ease-restrictions-ukraines-weapons-9363533/", "title": "NATO ministers meet in Prague as allies ease restrictions on Ukraine's use of their weapons | World News - The Indian Express", "body": "\"This is a matter of upholding international law -- Ukraine's right to self-defence,\" NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said. \"Russia has attacked Ukraine, (which) has the right to defend themselves. And that includes also attacking military legitimate targets inside Russia.\"\n\nNATO foreign ministers were meeting in the Czech capital Friday to prepare for this summer's leaders' summit as the alliance boosts support for Ukraine and countries one-by-one remove restrictions on how Kyiv can use western-supplied weaponry to combat Russia's invasion.\n\nA day after US President Joe Biden gave Ukraine the go-ahead to use American munitions to strike inside Russia for the limited purpose of defending Kharkiv, numerous ministers, including those from the Netherlands, Finland, Poland and Germany, expressed approval of the decision, saying that Ukraine has the absolute right to defend itself from attacks originating on Russian soil.\n\nThe chorus of allied voices backing greater leeway for Ukraine to use their weapons grew louder in recent weeks after Russia launched artillery strikes on Kharkiv from its territory, prompting appeals for help from Kyiv. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken had hinted strongly this week that a change in Washington's position was coming.\n\n\"This is a matter of upholding international law -- Ukraine's right to self-defence,\" NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said. \"Russia has attacked Ukraine, (which) has the right to defend themselves. And that includes also attacking military legitimate targets inside Russia.\"\n\nRead Also | What Ukraine's allies have said about striking Russia with Western weapons\n\n\"If you look at the battlefield now, Russia is launching attacks on Ukraine's soil from Russian soil with artillery, missiles, and massing troops,\" he said. \"And, of course, it makes it very hard for Ukraine to defend themselves if they are not allowed to use advanced weapons to repel those attacks.\"\n\nUkrainian officials had stepped up calls on the US administration to allow their forces to defend themselves against attacks originating from Russian territory. Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city, is just 20 km (12 miles) from the Russian border.\n\nUkrainian officials, most notably President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, have been increasingly vocal in arguing that the restriction was putting Ukrainian forces in an untenable situation as Russia intensified attacks around Kharkiv.\n\nRead Also | Russia finalising work on 'retaliatory measures' against EU over ban on some Russian media\n\nRussia has been exploiting a lengthy delay in replenishment of US military aid and Western Europe's inadequate military production that has slowed crucial deliveries to the battlefield for Ukraine.\n\nThe alliance is celebrating its 75th anniversary this year and leaders will be meeting in Washington in July to reaffirm their support. Stoltenberg said he expects to be able to announce at the summit that at least two-thirds of members are meeting their commitment to spend 2% of their gross domestic product on defence.", "source": {"uri": "8154722169", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "08:22:28", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T08:22:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T08:21:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.zawya.com/en/world/russia/nato-downplays-kremlin-threat-over-us-weapons-as-5-killed-in-kharkiv-km6kh9za", "title": "NATO downplays Kremlin threat over US weapons as 5 killed in Kharkiv", "body": "NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg Friday downplayed Kremlin threats of escalation after President Joe Biden secretly lifted restrictions on Ukraine using US-supplied weapons against targets inside Russian territory, as five people were killed in an overnight strike on Kharkiv.\n\nThe daily pounding of Ukraine's second-biggest city has caused a shift in Washington's thinking, which has heretofore resisted allowing Ukraine to use longer-range US weapons to attack Russian territory, fearing it could drag NATO into the direct conflict with Russia.\n\nThe Kremlin accused the West on Thursday of \"entering a new round of escalations in tensions\".\n\nStoltenberg, speaking to reporters at a meeting of NATO foreign ministers in Prague, responded that \"this is part of efforts by President (Vladimir) Putin and Moscow to prevent NATO allies from supporting Ukraine to defend themselves, and, again, Ukraine has the right for self defence and we have the right to help Ukraine.\"\n\nUS officials said Thursday that Biden had lifted restrictions on Ukraine using weapons supplied by the United States against targets on Russian territory, but only to defend Kharkiv.\n\nOvernight, Russian strikes on a residential area in Kharkiv city killed five people and wounded at least 23 others, including two children, regional police said early Friday, warning residents could still be trapped under the rubble.\n\n\"The rescue and search operation continues. All services are working at the scene,\" said Oleg Synyegubov, Head of Kharkiv Region Military Administration.\n\nKharkiv Mayor Igor Terekhov said there had not been \"a single military person, not a single military object\" present.\n\nThe city is located just across the border from Russia's Belgorod and regularly comes under attack from Russian missiles.\n\nRussian strikes that hit a hardware superstore in Kharkiv last weekend killed 16 people.\n\nOn the other side of the border, in Russia's southern Krasnodar region, Russia's military said on Friday that it had shot down 29 Ukrainian drones overnight that were targeting the port city of Novorossiisk and an oil depot in Temryuk.\n\nThe Temryuk strike sparked a fire, which raged for several hours before being extinguished, and wounded several oil depot workers, Krasnodar Region Governor Venyamin Kondratyev wrote on the Telegram social media channel.\n\nNo injuries were reported in the Novorossiisk strike, local authorities said.\n\nRestrictions lifted\n\nA US official said Biden \"had recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use US-supplied weapons or counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them.\"\n\nThe official said that ATACMS missiles, which could hit deeper inside Russia, were still prohibited.\n\nA second US official confirmed the change of policy, which followed weeks of behind-the-scenes discussions between the White House and top US military and State Department officials.\n\nBiden gave the final sign-off in recent days, but the decision was kept secret for operational reasons and only became effective on Thursday.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron had insisted this week that Ukraine be allowed to \"neutralise\" bases in Russia used to launch strikes.\n\nGerman Chancellor Olaf Scholz has remained cool to the idea, though his country did promise {"uri": "8154082761", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-30", "time": "21:48:36", "dateTime": "2024-05-30T21:48:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T21:47:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.ft.com/content/cae8f22b-4b12-4bcd-acc8-31deeff7cc42", "title": "Joe Biden allows Ukraine to use US weapons to hit targets in Russia", "body": "Joe Biden has approved Kyiv's use of American-made weapons to strike within Russia as long as the targets relate to Moscow's offensive in Ukraine's Kharkiv region, a US official said on Thursday.\n\nThe decision marks an important shift from Washington's previous position that Ukraine should not use US weapons to strike targets in Russia -- and follows growing pressure on Biden from Kyiv and its allies.\n\nPresident Volodymyr Zelenskyy's office did not immediately confirm or comment on the US decision. He and Ukrainian government officials had for weeks urged Washington to lift the restrictions, arguing that it was \"unfair\" that they were prohibited from striking military targets while Moscow's forces pounded civilian targets in Ukraine.\n\n\"The most important and immediate effect is that Ukraine will be able to strike targets at greater depths with Himars GMLRS munitions, including Russian artillery, electronic warfare, air defences and command posts,\" said Rob Lee, a senior fellow in the Foreign Policy Research Institute's Eurasia Program.\n\n\"Before now, Ukraine has been forced to move artillery too close to the front to engage targets at greater depth, which put them at greater risk.\"\n\nBut the US president's move on Thursday falls short of a sweeping greenlight for Ukraine to use US weapons to strike everywhere inside Russia.\n\n\"The president recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use US-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" a US official said on Thursday. \"Our policy with respect to prohibiting the use of Atacms or long-range strikes inside of Russia has not changed,\" the official added, referring to a US ballistic missile system.\n\nSince the start of Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022, Biden has opposed the use of US weapons to strike inside Russian territory for fear of escalating the conflict and drawing the US and Nato directly into war with Moscow.\n\nBut in recent weeks the president has been weighing a partial change to that policy in light of the Russian offensive in Kharkiv, in Ukraine's north-east.\n\nMoscow opened a new front in the region earlier this month, sending more than 30,000 ground forces into Ukraine from Russia's Belgorod region, according to Oleksandr Lytvynenko, Ukrainian national security and defence council secretary.\n\nRussia seized roughly a dozen Ukrainian villages and laid waste to the town of Vovchansk as it moved to create a so-called buffer zone that Lytvynenko said is meant to keep Kyiv's forces from launching attacks across the border.\n\nRussia has used warplanes and ground launchers to fire powerful glide bombs, missiles and heavy artillery at Kharkiv city and surrounding areas, killing dozens of civilians as it pounds targets just across the border.\n\nBiden's move comes as he prepares to travel to Europe next week for the 80th commemoration of D-Day in Normandy, and a state visit to Paris hosted by French President Emmanuel Macron, who has backed Ukraine's ability to strike targets inside Russia with western weapons.\n\nThe Financial Times has also reported that Biden and Zelenskyy will sign a bilateral security deal at a G7 summit in Italy next later in June, cementing long-term defence ties between the US and Ukraine.", "source": {"uri": "ft.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Financial {"uri": "2024-05-374003210", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "04:51:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T04:51:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T04:45:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com.au/deadly-strikes-kharkiv-biden-lets-ukraine-use-us-arms-inside-russia-1848381", "title": "Deadly Strikes On Kharkiv As Biden Lets Ukraine Use US Arms Inside Russia", "body": "Russian strikes killed three people in the Ukrainian city of Kharkiv, authorities said Friday, after the United States had authorised Kyiv to use American weapons to hit targets inside Russia in defence of the region.\n\nWith Russia having retaken the battlefield initiative in recent months, Ukraine had doubled down on calls to permit it to use longer-range US weapons to attack Russian territory -- something Washington had resisted over fears it could drag NATO into direct conflict with Moscow.\n\nBut that calculus changed after Russian forces launched a fresh offensive in the Kharkiv region this month.\n\nOvernight Russian strikes on a residential area in Kharkiv city killed three people and wounded at least 23 others, including two children, regional police said early Friday, warning residents could still be trapped under the rubble.\n\n\"A man and a woman were killed as a result of an enemy munition hitting a multi-storey residential building... The fourth and fifth floors of one of the building's sections were completely destroyed,\" police said in a statement, adding that another munition killed a guard at a civilian production facility.\n\nRegional Governor Oleg Synegubov noted in a Telegram post that an emergency medic was among the wounded, adding: \"The enemy again used a double strike tactic, while medics, rescuers and law enforcement officers were already working on the spot.\"\n\nKharkiv Mayor Igor Terekhov said there had not been \"a single military person, not a single military object\" present.\n\nUkraine's second-largest city, Kharkiv is located just across the border from Russia's Belgorod and regularly comes under attack from Russian missiles.\n\nRussian strikes that hit a hardware superstore in the city last weekend killed 16 people.\n\nOn the other side of the border, in Russia's southern Krasnodar region, an oil depot was damaged in an aerial attack, its governor said Friday morning, noting that a major drone incursion elsewhere in the region had been repelled by air defences.\n\n\"The situation is more serious in Temryuk district -- the oil depot infrastructure there was damaged by an air strike. Three tanks with petroleum products were damaged and are on fire,\" Governor Veniamin Kondratyev said on Telegram, adding some workers had been wounded.\n\nUS officials said Thursday that President Joe Biden had lifted restrictions on Ukraine using weapons supplied by the United States against targets on Russian territory, but only to defend Kharkiv.\n\n\"The president recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use US-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" a US official said on condition of anonymity.\n\nA second US official confirmed the change of policy, which followed weeks of behind-the-scenes discussions between the White House and top US military and State Department officials.\n\nBiden gave the final sign-off in recent days, but the decision was kept secret for operational reasons and only became effective on Thursday.\n\nThe White House has made it clear to Kyiv that the permission for cross-border attacks was limited to targets just over the border that were being used to launch offensives.\n\nAhead of a NATO meeting in Prague on Thursday, alliance chief Jens Stoltenberg had said repeatedly that it was time for members to reconsider limits on strikes inside Russia.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron had also insisted this week that Ukraine be allowed to \"neutralise\" bases in Russia used to launch strikes.\n\nGerman Chancellor Olaf Scholz has remained cool to the idea, though his country did promise Ukraine a new package of military aid worth 500 million euros ($540 million) on Thursday.\n\nThe Kremlin, for its part, accused the West on Thursday of \"entering a new round of escalations in tensions\" in recent days.\n\nThe Pentagon, meanwhile, released a new report Wednesday citing debris analysis to confirm long-standing allegations that North Korea has been supplying Russia with weapons for use in Ukraine.\n\nThe report by the Pentagon's Defense Intelligence Agency used open-source imagery to confirm that debris found in the Kharkiv region in January was from a short-range ballistic missile made in North Korea.\n\n\"North Korean missile debris was found throughout Ukraine,\" the report said.\n\nSouth Korea has accused Pyongyang of sending thousands of containers of munitions to Russia, which would violate rafts of UN sanctions on both countries.\n\nThe powerful sister of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un this month called the allegations \"absurd\".\n\nBut experts say a recent weapons It has (...) been the case for a long time that every time NATO allies are providing support to Ukraine, President Putin is trying to threaten us to not do that,\" he told reporters.\n\n\"And an escalation - well, Russia has escalated by invading another country.\"\n\nPutin on Tuesday warned NATO members against allowing Ukraine to fire their weapons into Russia and raised anew a risk of nuclear war after several allies lifted restrictions imposed on the use of weapons donated to Kyiv.\n\nIn a marked policy shift, U.S. President Joe Biden has also authorized Kyiv the limited use of U.S.-supplied weapons inside Russia, four officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said on Thursday.\n\nBiden's decision applies only to targets inside Russia near the border with the Kharkiv region, where an offensive launched by Moscow on May 10 has overrun some villages, they explained. The U.S. is by far the largest arms donor to Kyiv.\n\nKharkiv, Ukraine's second largest city, is 19 miles (30 km) from the border with Russia.\n\nStoltenberg said Ukraine had the right to strike legitimate military targets inside Russia, especially since the borderline and the frontline near Kharkiv were more or less the same, and it was not reasonable to assume Kyiv should not hit back.\n\n\"Of course it makes it very hard for Ukraine to defend themselves if they are not allowed to use advanced weapons to repel those attacks,\" he said.\n\n\"Ukraine has the right for self-defence, we have the right to help Ukraine uphold the right for self-defence, and that does not make NATO allies a party to the conflict,\" Stoltenberg added.\n\n\"That was the case back in on Kharkiv kill 3 after Biden approves use of US arms inside Russia", "body": "But that calculus appears to have changed since Russian forces launched a fresh offensive in the Kharkiv region this month.\n\nA Russian missile strike in Kharkiv city killed three people and wounded at least 16 others, regional Governor Oleg Synegubov said in a post on Telegram early Friday morning, noting an emergency medic was among the wounded and an ambulance was damaged.\n\n\"The enemy again used a double strike tactic, while medics, rescuers and law enforcement officers were already working on the spot,\" Synegubov said.\n\nKharkiv Mayor Igor Terekhov said in an interview with local media there could be more people trapped under the rubble of the residential building, adding: \"There was not a single military person, not a single military object\" present.\n\nTerekhov later put the number of wounded at 23.\n\nKharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city, is located just across the border from Russia's Belgorod and regularly comes under attack from Russian missiles.\n\nRussian strikes that hit a hardware superstore in the city last weekend killed 16 people.\n\nRestrictions lifted\n\nUS officials said Thursday that President Joe Biden had lifted restrictions on Ukraine using weapons supplied by the United States against targets on Russian territory, but only to defend the Kharkiv region.\n\n\"The president recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use US-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" a US official said on condition of anonymity.\n\nA second US official confirmed the change of policy.\n\nUS Secretary of State Antony Blinken had hinted on Wednesday that Biden could change course.\n\nBlinken, who visited Ukraine earlier this month, said the United States had \"adapted and adjusted\" as the \"battlefield has changed\" in remarks to reporters in Moldova on the eve of NATO talks in Prague.\n\nAhead of the NATO meeting, alliance chief Jens Stoltenberg had also said repeatedly that it was time for members to reconsider the limits on strikes inside Russia.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron appeared to shift the dial forward on Tuesday when he said Ukraine should be allowed to \"neutralise\" bases in Russia used to launch strikes.\n\nGerman Chancellor Olaf Scholz, however, remained less sure, saying Ukraine should act within the law -- and Berlin had not supplied weapons that could hit Russia anyway.\n\nGermany did, however, promise Ukraine a new package of military aid worth 500 million euros ($540 million) on Thursday, with the defence ministry saying it included \"artillery, air defence (and) drones\".\n\nThe Kremlin, for its part, accused the West on Thursday of \"entering a new round of escalations in tensions\" in recent days.\n\n\"They are provoking Ukraine in every possible way {"uri": "8155028338", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "11:35:13", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T11:35:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T11:34:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://asianlite.com/2024/top-news/biden-allows-use-of-us-weapons-for-limited-ukrainian-strikes/", "title": "Biden allows use of US weapons for limited Ukrainian strikes - Asian News from UK", "body": "Under the new directive, Ukraine is permitted to retaliate against Russian forces or targets located near Kharkiv using weaponry supplied by the United States....reports Asian Lite News\n\nIn a significant shift from longstanding policy, President Joe Biden has authorised Ukraine to conduct targeted strikes within Russian territory using American munitions.\n\nThis decision comes amidst escalating tensions as Russian forces make significant advances near Kharkiv, a city in northeastern Ukraine close to the Russian border, according to two US officials briefed on the matter.\n\nUnder the new directive, Ukraine is permitted to retaliate against Russian forces or targets located near Kharkiv using weaponry supplied by the United States.\n\n\"The president recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use US-supplied weapons for counterfire purposes in Kharkiv so Ukraine can hit back at Russian forces hitting them or preparing to hit them,\" one official said.\n\nThis policy adjustment, however, is strictly confined to the vicinity of Kharkiv, with no plans to expand the permitted area, the official added. Ukrainian authorities have not sought permission for strikes beyond this region.\n\nThe request for this policy change was made by Kyiv in response to the advancing Russian forces in recent weeks, the official confirmed. Ukrainian forces are now empowered to target Russian military installations, ammunition depots, and logistical hubs across the border from Kharkiv in western Russia.\n\nNevertheless, the Biden administration has maintained its stance against allowing Ukraine to utilize its most formidable munitions, including the long-range ATACMS missiles, which have a range of up to 200 miles (300 kilometers).\n\nSecretary of State Antony Blinken hinted at the possibility of adjusting the administration's approach earlier this week. \"Another hallmark of our support for Ukraine over the last two years has been to adapt as the conditions have changed,\" Blinken remarked during a visit to Moldova. \"I am confident we will continue to do that.\"\n\nThe shift in policy aligns with recent statements from European leaders, including French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz. Macron emphasised the need for Ukraine to neutralise military sites within Russia that pose a threat to Ukrainian territory. \"Ukrainian soil is being attacked from bases in Russia,\" Macron stated.\n\n\"We think that we should allow them to neutralise the military sites from which the missiles are fired and, basically, the military sites from which Ukraine is attacked.\"\n\nScholz echoed Macron's sentiments, affirming that Ukraine has the right to defend itself within the parameters set by the countries supplying the weapons and international law. {"uri": "2024-05-374206216", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "08:34:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T08:34:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T04:17:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-05-31/russian-missiles-kill-4-people-in-kharkiv-after-biden-oks-a-ukrainian-response-using-u-s-weapons", "title": "Russian Missiles Kill 4 People in Kharkiv After Biden OKs a Ukrainian Response Using U.S. Weapons", "body": "KYIV, Ukraine (AP) -- Russian ballistic missiles slammed into an apartment block in Kharkiv and killed at least four people in a night-time attack, Ukrainian officials said Friday, a day after U.S. President Joe Biden gave Kyiv a green light to strike back with American weapons at Russian military assets targeting the country's second-largest city.\n\nRussia launched five S-300/S-400 ballistic missiles at Kharkiv overnight, Ukraine's air force said. One of them struck a residential building close to midnight and was followed by another missile 25 minutes later that hit first responders, according to regional Gov. Oleh Syniehubov. At least 25 people were injured, he said.\n\nUkrainian officials have previously accused Russia of targeting rescue workers by hitting residential buildings with two consecutive missiles -- the first one to draw emergency crews to the scene and the second one to wound or kill them. The tactic is called a \"double tap\" in military jargon. Russia used the same method in Syria's civil war.\n\nA Russian onslaught this month in the northeastern Kharkiv region, including a Russian aerial bomb attack on a large construction supplies store that killed 18 people on May 25, has forced the evacuation of thousands of people and has stretched Ukraine's depleted forces in what is proving to be a critical period in the war, which is now in its third year.\n\nApart from Kharkiv, Moscow's troops are pressing in the Donetsk region further south and are assembling a force for an expected attack in the Sumy region further north, according to Ukrainian officials,\n\nThe Kremlin's bigger and better-equipped army is exploiting Ukrainian shortages in troops and ammunition after a lengthy delay in U.S. military aid. Western Europe's inadequate military production has slowed crucial deliveries of military aid to Ukraine.\n\nBiden's decision allows for U.S.-supplied weapons to be used for \"counterfire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" one Washington official told The Associated Press.\n\nBut the officials, who requested anonymity to discuss the sensitive matter, stressed that the U.S. policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.\n\nThat restriction has frustrated Ukrainian officials as the military is unable to order hits on Russian troops massing across the border -- Kharkiv city is only 20 kilometers (12 miles) from Russia -- or Russian bases used to launch missile attacks.\n\nThe question of whether to allow Ukraine to hit targets on Russian soil with Western-supplied weaponry has been a delicate issue since Moscow launched its full-scale invasion on Feb. 24, 2022.\n\nWestern leaders have hesitated to take the step because it runs the risk of provoking Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has repeatedly warned that the West's direct involvement could put the world on a path to nuclear conflict.\n\nBut as Russia has recently gained the battlefield initiative in some parts of the 1,000-kilometer (600-mile) front line, some Western leaders are pushing for a policy change allowing Kyiv to strike military bases inside Russia with sophisticated long-range weapons provided by its Western partners.\n\n___\n\nFollow AP's coverage of the war in Ukraine at https://apnews.com/hub/russia-ukraine\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://arab.news/g99cv", "title": "Biden allows Ukraine to use US-supplied arms to strike inside Russia", "body": "Some countries including Britain and the Netherlands say Kyiv has the right to use their weapons to strike military targets in Russia\n\nWASHINGTON: President Joe Biden has lifted restrictions on Ukraine using weapons supplied by the United States against targets on Russian territory, but only to defend the under-fire Kharkiv region, US officials said Thursday.\n\nBiden has come under increasing pressure from a desperate Ukraine to ease his ban, but had so far resisted amid fears it could drag NATO into direct conflict with Moscow.\n\n\"The president recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use US-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" a US official said on condition of anonymity.\n\n\"Our policy with respect to prohibiting the use of ATACMS or long range strikes inside of Russia has not changed,\" the official said, referring to long-range missiles recently sent by Washington to Kyiv.\n\nA second US official confirmed Biden's change of policy.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has been pressing Kyiv's supporters -- chiefly the United States -- to allow it to use the longer-range weaponry they supply to hit targets on Russian soil.\n\nSome countries including Britain and the Netherlands say Kyiv has the right to use their weapons to strike military targets in Russia.\n\nUS Secretary of State Antony Blinken had hinted on Wednesday that Biden could change course.\n\nBlinken said the United States had \"adapted and adjusted\" as the \"battlefield has changed,\" as he spoke to reporters on a visit to Moldova on the eve of NATO talks in Prague.\n\nBlinken, who traveled Kyiv earlier this month to see the increasingly grave situation as Russia pushes forward toward Kharkiv, had been widely reported to be pressing Biden to ease the rules.\n\nAhead of the NATO meeting, which starts with a dinner on Thursday, alliance chief Jens Stoltenberg said repeatedly it was time for members to reconsider those limits because they hampered Kyiv's ability to defend itself.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron appeared to shift the dial forward on Tuesday when he said Ukraine should be allowed to \"neutralize\" bases in Russia used to launch strikes.\n\nGerman Chancellor Olaf Scholz, however, remained less sure, saying Ukraine should act within the law -- and Berlin had not supplied weapons that could hit Russia anyway.\n\nPressure has also been mounting ahead of a series of key meetings in Europe in coming weeks where Kyiv's plight will be in focus.\n\nBiden will attend ceremonies in France marking the World War II D-Day landings in early June where Ukraine's Zelensky will also be present.\n\nThe US president will also meet leaders of {"uri": "8154307028", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "02:30:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T02:30:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T02:28:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.asiaone.com/world/biden-secretly-gave-ukraine-permission-strike-inside-russia-us-arms-politico-reports", "title": "AsiaOne", "body": "WASHINGTON/PRAGUE -- President Joe Biden quietly has authorised Kyiv to launch US-supplied weapons at military targets inside Russia that are supporting an offencive against the northeastern Ukrainian city of Kharkiv, four US officials said on Thursday (May 30).\n\nThe decision marks a policy shift by Biden, who had steadfastly refused to allow Ukraine to use American weaponry for strikes inside Russia.\n\nRussia's embassy in Washington and Russia's mission to the United Nations in New York did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nThe US officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Biden's decision applies only to targets inside Russia near the border with the Kharkiv region, where an offencive launched by Moscow on May 10 has overrun some villages.\n\n\"The President recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use US-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" said one US official.\n\nRussia is building up forces near the northern part of the region, but it lacks the troop numbers to stage a major push, Ukraine's top commander said on Thursday.\n\nKharkiv, Ukraine's second largest city, is 19 miles (30 km) from the border with Russia.\n\nIt is the second time this year that Biden has quietly relaxed his policy on weapons supplies for Ukraine, bending to calls to send long-range missiles known as ATACMS to Kyiv.\n\n\"The Biden administration has come a long way from their hypersensitivity to and misunderstanding of the risk of escalation,\" said Alexander Vindman, a retired Army lieutenant colonel and former director for European affairs at the White House National Security Council under the Trump administration.\n\nHe applauded the shift in Biden's policy, which he said \"unties Ukraine's hands.\"\n\n\"Of course it's the right move,\" Vindman said.\n\nThe US is the biggest supplier of weapons to Ukraine in its battle against the full-scale invasion launched by Russian President Vladimir Putin in February 2022.\n\nThe officials said that US policy would continue to prohibit the Ukrainian military from using ATACMS, which have a range of up to 186 miles (300 km), and other long-range US-supplied weapons for deep strikes inside Russia.\n\nBiden's decision also does not mean the US now approves of drone attacks that Ukraine has been launching against Russian petroleum facilities, they said.\n\nSome Nato allies and US lawmakers have been calling on Biden to relax the restriction on US weapons to allow Ukraine to strike missile launchers and other military sites inside Russia that are backing Moscow's drive toward Kharkiv.\n\nRussia jetfighters flying inside Russia out of reach of Ukrainian air defences have been supporting the offencive by loosing highly precise glide bombs at Ukrainian defence lines and into Kharkiv, where they have caused numerous civilian casualties.\n\nPutin on Tuesday warned Nato members against allowing Ukraine to fire their weapons into Russia and he raised anew a risk of nuclear war.\n\nSome experts dismissed his remarks as bluster. They noted that Putin has failed to act on similar threats in the past and already has committed the bulk of his conventional forces to Europe's biggest land war since World War Two.\n\n\"I don't think we can or should be bullied by Vladimir Putin,\" said US Representative Gerry Connolly, a Democratic member of the House of Representatives Foreign Affairs Committee. \"Is he really willing to risk nuclear war and a conflict with Nato?\"\n\nConnolly co-signed a May 20 letter with Representative Michael Turner, the Republican chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, and other lawmakers urging the Biden administration to allow Ukraine to use US weapons to hit strategic targets inside Russia.\n\nFor some time, critics have urged Nato allies to relax restrictions on use of their weapons against military targets inside Russia. Those voices have grown within the alliance since Russia launched the Kharkiv offencive.\n\nCountries that have called for relaxing restrictions or done so for their own arms sent to Ukraine include Britain, the Netherlands, Sweden, the Baltic states, Finland, Denmark, Germany and France.\n\nBiden faced the potentially embarrassing prospect that as he hosts a Nato summit in July, Russian forces would be advancing on Kharkiv and in Ukraine's east as the alliance marks its 75th anniversary, analysts said.\n\n[embed]https://twitter.com/BRICSinfo/status/1794422625571393724[/embed]", "source": The U.S., however, is not alone in reconsidering its previous decision not to allow Ukraine to use its weapons to hit targets in Russia.\n\nBiden's new policy allows for Ukrainian forces to hit Russian missiles heading toward Kharkiv and at troops massing just over the Russian border near the city, though they are still not permitted to hit civilian infrastructure or hit targets deep inside Russian territory.\n\n\"The President recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use U.S.-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" a State Department spokesperson told the Washington Examiner. \"Our policy with respect to prohibiting the use of ATACMS or long range strikes inside of Russia has not changed.\"\n\nSecretary of State Antony Blinken hinted that the president was shifting his stance a day earlier.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\n\"We're going to make sure that it has the equipment it needs to do that. And another hallmark of our support for Ukraine over these now more than two years has been to adapt. As the conditions have changed, as the battlefield has changed, as what Russia does has changed in terms of how it's pursuing its aggression, escalation, we've adapted and adjusted too, and I'm confident we'll continue to do that,\" the secretary said.\n\nMultiple NATO countries have announced publicly that Ukraine could use its military assistance to hit targets inside Russian territory this month despite continued hesitation from others. France, Canada, and the United Kingdom have said Ukraine can use their weapons to hit targets in Russia as well.\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE WASHINGTON EXAMINER\n\nSince the beginning of Russia's invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, the U.S. and NATO have sought to avoid escalating tension with Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has repeatedly issued threats of nuclear escalation.\n\nBiden has shifted his thinking several times during the war, most often loosening previous restrictions or deciding to provide Ukraine with weapons the U.S. had been previously opposed to giving the country at all.\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. {"uri": "8154190016", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "00:01:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T00:01:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T00:00:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://nypost.com/2024/05/30/us-news/biden-gives-ukraine-permission-to-use-us-weapons-to-attack-russia/", "title": "Biden gives Ukraine permission to use US weapons to attack Russia", "body": "President Biden has given Ukraine the green light to use US-provided weapons to hit some targets in Russian territory, according to a US official.\n\n\"The President recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use US-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" the US official said Thursday.\n\nThe official noted, however, that Ukraine will not be allowed to use long-range US weapons to hit military targets deep inside Russian territory.\n\nThe US-supplied Army Tactical Missile System, for instance, can make strikes at a range of 200 miles.\n\n\"Our policy with respect to prohibiting the use of ATACMS or long range strikes inside of Russia has not changed,\" the US official said.\n\nThe announcement marks a shift in long standing US policy, which prevented Ukraine from using American firepower to hit Russian troops and military installations on Russian soil.\n\nThe restriction was put in place over the Biden administration's fears that American weapons killing Russians in Russia would lead to an escalation in the war.\n\nThe change in policy comes as Russian troops have made advances on Ukraine's second-largest city, Kharkiv.\n\nThe northeastern Ukrainian city sits just 30 miles south of Russia's border with the war-torn country and has recently seen some of the most intense fighting of the 27-month-long conflict.\n\nIn recent weeks, the Kremlin has touted its military advancements in the region, claiming to have captured villages around Kharkiv as part of a broad push into the region that would allow it to get within artillery range of the city.\n\nRussian troops began their offensive on the region on May 10.\n\nSince then, the US has announced some $675 million in military aid for Ukraine, in the form of High Mobility Artillery Rocket Systems (HIMARS) and ammunition; Howitzer artillery rounds; High-speed Anti-radiation missiles (HARMs) and other \"urgently needed\" pieces of offensive and defensive equipment and ammunition.\n\nThe Biden administration has provided Ukraine with five aid packages of weapons pulled from existing Defense Department stockpiles since Congress approved $60 billion in additional funding last month.\n\nCongressional lawmakers were briefed by US military officials in early May about the \"value\" in easing restrictions on Ukraine's use of U.S. weapons, according to Politico.\n\nThe formal decision to change the policy came only {"uri": "2024-05-374222109", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "08:49:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T08:49:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T08:40:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/world-news/2024/05/31/russian-missiles-hit-apartment-block-in-ukrainian-city/", "title": "Russian missiles hit apartment block in Ukrainian city", "body": "At least four people died in the attack in Kharkiv, officials said.\n\nRussian ballistic missiles have slammed into an apartment block in Kharkiv, killing at least four people, Ukrainian officials said.\n\nThe night-time attack came a day after President Joe Biden gave Kyiv the green light to strike back with American weapons at Russian military assets targeting Kharkiv, which is Ukraine's second-largest city.\n\nRussia launched five S-300/S-400 ballistic missiles at Kharkiv overnight, Ukraine's air force said.\n\nOne of them struck a residential building close to midnight and was followed by another missile 25 minutes later that hit first responders, according to regional governor Oleh Syniehubov. At least 25 people were injured, he said.\n\nUkrainian officials have previously accused Russia of targeting rescue workers by hitting residential buildings with two consecutive missiles -- the first one to draw emergency crews to the scene and the second one to wound or kill them.\n\nThe tactic is called a \"double tap\" in military jargon, and Russia used the same method in Syria's civil war.\n\nA Russian onslaught this month in the north-eastern Kharkiv region, including a Russian aerial bomb attack on a large construction supplies store that killed 18 people on May 25, has forced the evacuation of thousands of people and has stretched Ukraine's depleted forces.\n\nApart from Kharkiv, Moscow's troops are pressing in the Donetsk region further south and are assembling a force for an expected attack in the Sumy region further north, according to Ukrainian officials,\n\nThe Kremlin's bigger and better-equipped army is exploiting Ukrainian shortages in troops and ammunition after a lengthy delay in US military aid. Western Europe's inadequate military production has slowed crucial deliveries of military aid to Ukraine.\n\nMr Biden's decision allows for US-supplied weapons to be used for \"counterfire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them\", one Washington official told The Associated Press.\n\nBut the officials stressed that the US policy calling on Ukraine not to use American-provided ATACMS or long-range missiles and other munitions to strike offensively inside Russia has not changed.\n\nThat restriction has frustrated Ukrainian officials as the military is unable to order hits on Russian troops massing across the border. Kharkiv city is only 12 miles from Russia and Russian bases used to launch missile attacks.\n\nThe question of whether to allow Ukraine to hit targets on Russian soil with Western-supplied weaponry has been a delicate issue since Moscow launched its full-scale invasion on February 24 2022.\n\nWestern leaders have hesitated to take the step because it runs the risk of provoking Russian President Vladimir Putin, who has repeatedly warned that the West's direct involvement could put the world on a path to nuclear conflict.\n\nBut as Russia has recently gained the battlefield initiative on some parts of the 600-mile front line, some Western leaders are pushing for a policy change allowing Kyiv to strike military bases inside Russia with sophisticated long-range weapons provided by its {"uri": "8154034281", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-30", "time": "21:00:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-30T21:00:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T20:59:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://dailycallernewsfoundation.org/2024/05/30/biden-privately-approved-ukraine-using-american-weapons-to-strike-inside-russia-report/", "title": "Biden Privately Approved Ukraine Using American Weapons To Strike Inside Russia: REPORT", "body": "President Joe Biden reportedly gave Ukraine permission to use American weapons to strike inside Russian territory, according to Politico.\n\nBiden's decision represents a major reversal on America's approach to the Russia-Ukraine war, as he had previously resisted calls to provide Ukrainian forces with offensive weapons to strike inside Russia, according to Politico, which cited anonymous U.S. officials and other sources familiar with the move. Ukrainian forces have suffered setbacks in the country's northeastern region, apparently prompting the policy reversal, but some Ukraine skeptics have cautioned that allowing strikes inside Russia with U.S. weapons could invite unwelcome and serious escalation from Russian President Vladimir Putin.\n\n\"The president recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use U.S. weapons for counter-fire purposes in Kharkiv so Ukraine can hit back at Russian forces hitting them or preparing to hit them,\" one U.S. official told Politico. The official added that the administration's policy of not permitting long-range strikes inside Russia's borders \"has not changed.\"\n\nUkrainian forces can now use U.S. weaponry to counter Russian missiles bound for Kharkiv, fire upon soldiers assembling inside Russia to attack nearby Kharkiv, or take down Russian bombers attacking Ukraine, according to Politico. However, the new stance will reportedly not allow Ukraine to use that firepower to target civilian infrastructure or launch long-range attacks against military installations further in the Russian interior.\n\nThe Biden administration had previously asserted that allowing Ukrainian strikes inside Russia with U.S.-provided weaponry could prompt Putin to escalate or broaden the conflict, according to Politico. However, the deteriorating situation around Kharkiv reportedly forced the administration to change its mind, especially as Ukrainian officials have emphasized their need to disrupt the buildup of troops pouring into the northeast from just over the border.\n\nOther U.S. allies that have contributed to Ukraine's war effort, including France and the U.K., have previously argued that the Ukrainians should be able to use weapons provided by the West to strike inside Russia's borders, according to Politico. Russia has cautioned that NATO risks escalation if the alliance permits Ukraine to use provided weapons to attack inside Russia, with Putin warning that allowing such attacks could \"lead to serious consequences.\"\n\nThe Department of Defense (DOD) declined to comment, and referred the Daily Caller News Foundation to the National Security Council (NSC). U.S. Arms To Defend Kharkiv - Official", "body": "President Joe Biden has lifted restrictions on Ukraine using weapons supplied by the United States against targets on Russian territory, but only to defend the under-fire Kharkiv region, U.S. officials said Thursday.\n\nBiden has come under increasing pressure from a desperate Ukraine to ease his ban but had so far resisted amid fears it could drag NATO into direct conflict with Moscow.\n\n\"The president recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use U.S.-supplied weapons for counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them,\" a U.S. official said on condition of anonymity.\n\n\"Our policy with respect to prohibiting the use of ATACMS or long-range strikes inside of Russia has not changed,\" the official said, referring to long-range missiles recently sent by Washington to Kyiv.\n\nA second U.S. official confirmed Biden's change of policy.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has been pressing Kyiv's supporters -- chiefly the United States -- to allow it to use the longer-range weaponry they supply to hit targets on Russian soil.\n\nSome countries including Britain and the Netherlands say Kyiv has the right to use their weapons to strike military targets in Russia.\n\nU.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken had hinted on Wednesday that Biden could change course.\n\nBlinken said the United States had \"adapted and adjusted\" as the \"battlefield has changed,\" as he spoke to reporters on a visit to Moldova on the eve of NATO talks in Prague.\n\nBlinken, who traveled to Kyiv earlier this month to see the increasingly grave situation as Russia pushes forward towards Kharkiv, had been widely reported to be pressing Biden to ease the rules.\n\nAhead of the NATO meeting, which starts with a dinner on Thursday, alliance chief Jens Stoltenberg said repeatedly it was time for members to reconsider those limits because they hampered Kyiv's ability to defend itself.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron appeared to shift the dial forward on Tuesday when he said Ukraine should be allowed to \"neutralize\" bases in Russia used to launch strikes.\n\nGerman Chancellor Olaf Scholz, however, remained less sure, saying Ukraine should act within the law -- and Berlin had not supplied weapons that could hit Russia anyway.\n\nPressure has also been mounting ahead of a series of key meetings in Europe in the coming weeks where Kyiv's plight will be in focus.\n\nBiden will attend ceremonies in France marking the World War II D-Day landings in early June where Ukraine's Zelensky will also be present.\n\nThe U.S. president will also meet leaders of the world's top economies at the G7 summit in But it is limited to the area around Kharkiv, and Ukraine has not requested permission beyond that, the official said, adding that they do not anticipate the US widening the area allowed.\n\nPolitico was first to report the news.\n\nKyiv made the request for Washington to change its policy in just the past few weeks as Russian forces have made their advance, the official said. Russian forces, ammunitions depots and logistical hubs can now be targeted with US-provided artillery and rockets across the border from Kharkiv in western Russia.\n\nThe administration is also standing firm in not allowing Ukraine to use the most formidable munition it has been given to fire into Russia: the long-range missiles known as ATACMS that can hit targets 200 miles, or 300 kilometers, away.\n\nUkraine has been allowed to use US anti-aircraft weapons to take down the imminent threat of Russian aircraft flying in both Ukrainian and Russian airspace and has done so successfully, the first official emphasized. as war escalates", "body": "US PRESIDENT Joe Biden has given Ukraine the go-ahead to hit back at Russia by using American weapons, top US officials say.\n\nUkraine has been constantly calling for additional support from the West with Biden finally responding with a partial change to US policy in a move that is all but certain to anger an already paranoid Vladimir Putin.\n\nThe major shake up comes as Russia continues to attack Ukraine's second largest city of Kharkiv as they look to seize more Ukrainian territory.\n\nBiden's secretive decision means US weapons can now be used by Ukraine for \"counter-fire purposes\" on their aggressors.\n\nOne of the three sources who announced the lifting of the ban said it will allow Ukraine to \"hit back at Russian forces hitting them or preparing to hit them.\"\n\nThe second anonymous source said Ukraine has been granted the \"flexibility\" to defend itself.\n\nThe move is set to help Ukraine bite back in Kharkiv as they try to push back Putin's soldiers.\n\nUkraine is thought to be looking to use US weapons, such as rockets, to blast Putin's missiles and drones out of the sky to spare Kharkiv.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has been increasingly vocal about his troops getting additional support from the West.\n\nPutin has been accused of exploiting the delay in fresh overseas military aid to Ukraine to step up his attacks in the besieged city.\n\nLeaving Ukraine severely under prepared on the frontlines.\n\nDespite the predicted new ruling, officials have maintained their stance that US weapons shouldn't be offensively used against Russia.\n\nMeaning Ukraine isn't allowed to attack Russian civilian infrastructure with any US supplied weapons.\n\nThey are also still banned from using long range weapons such as the army tactical missile system (ATACMS).\n\nThe officials say the decision was all down to President Biden.\n\nBiden was thought to be against allowing Ukraine to deal deadly blows with US weapons due to past comments declaring any such actions could be viewed as provocative to the Kremlin.\n\nThe US government has tried to stay as neutral as possible so far as to not anger Putin and cause a further escalation of war.\n\nBiden's Administration has also previously urged Ukraine to stop targeting Russian oil refineries warning strikes \"risk driving up global oil prices and provoking retaliation\".\n\nUkraine has struck at least half of Russia's 30 major refineries since January as the blasts cause great fires to break out and further humiliate Putin and his cronies.\n\nUS Secretary of State Antony Blinken said recently: \"As the conditions have changed, as the battlefield has changed, as what Russia does has changed in terms of how its pursuing its aggression and escalation, we've adapted and adjusted too.\n\nHe singled out Nato allies saying \"constant escalation can lead to serious consequences\".\n\nDespite the tyrant's strong warning, his own country has bombarded Ukraine with weapons from Iran, North Korea and China so far.\n\nFrench President Emmanuel Macron spoke with Nato chief Jens Stoltenberg this week as they announced Western countries should be helping Ukraine defend itself.\n\nStoltenberg said: \"We need to remember what it is. This is a war of aggression launched by choice by Moscow against Ukraine.\n\n\"I believe that time has come to reconsider some of these restrictions to enable the Ukrainians to really defend themselves.\"\n\nThe Czech Foreign Minister Jan Lipavsky agreed saying Ukraine is in desperate need of resources to counter Russia's relentless threats.\n\nNorway say they believe that under second-largest city Kharkiv is now seeing intense fighting as Putin's troops look to push forward into the northeast.\n\nKharkiv's mayor Ihor Terekhov has begged the West to step in and accused Vlad of terrorising its 1.3 million residents and plunging the city into darkness.\n\nRussian attacks on Kharkiv - liberated after six months of Moscow's occupation in September 2022 - have been scaling up dramatically in previous weeks, killing dozens and leaving thousands without electricity.\n\nTerekhov said that unless the West steps up and delivers crucial air defence systems - Kharkiv could suffer the same fate as the Syrian city of Aleppo, which heavy Russian bombing helped to decimate a decade ago.\n\nLast Saturday, at least 18 people were killed after a Russian missile strike hit a retail park in the region sparking a horror inferno.\n\nDramatic footage shows massive plumes of black smoke rising into the Kharkiv sky after the Epicentre construction hypermarket became engulfed by flames.\n\nWitnesses told our Sun reporter on the scene there were 200 people inside the 10,000sqft construction hypermarket.\n\nHero Brit volunteer Tony Ferret, 34, of Rye, Kent, was among those trying to help as the sky filled with black smoke.\n\nHe told The Sun: \"They were trying to move vehicles out of the way so they could get the fire engines in.\n\nMeanwhile, Ukraine claimed Putin's Russia reached a grim milestone after losing more than 500,000 soldiers in their failing war.\n\nKyiv said Moscow's crumbling army has also lost some 22,000 tanks and armoured vehicles and nearly 700 We have had enough of this, and it is more than eloquent evidence of the extent of the United States' involvement in this conflict.\"\n\nIn the lead-up to a meeting of NATO foreign ministers in Prague, key European allies pressed to lift restrictions. On Thursday, the White House said Biden did just that, granting Ukrainian forces the ability to hit back at Russian forces attacking them in and around Kharkiv.\n\nThe shift grants Ukraine permission to use U.S.-provided artillery and rocket launchers to hit Russian troops and equipment just across the border from Kharkiv and to strike missiles headed toward Ukrainian territory, according to U.S. officials. They stressed that the Biden administration's policy barring longer-range strikes inside Russia has not changed.\n\nAfter the U.S. announcement, Germany, a holdout, quickly followed suit, saying Ukrainian soldiers have the right to use German weapons to hit back. \"In recent weeks, Russia has prepared, coordinated and carried out attacks, particularly in the Kharkiv area, from positions in the immediately adjacent Russian border area,\" Germany said in a statement.\n\n\"Ukraine has the right under international law to defend itself against these attacks,\" the statement continued. \"To this end, [Ukraine] can also use the weapons supplied for this purpose in accordance with its international legal obligations, including those supplied by us.\"\n\nIn recent months, dire conditions on the battlefield have pushed Ukraine's supporters to consider options once deemed too escalatory.\n\nIn February, French President Emmanuel Macron surprised many by saying \"no option should be discarded\" in response to a question about sending Western troops to Ukraine.\n\nIn recent days, top Ukrainian officials have said they are in discussions with Paris about sending French military trainers to Ukraine. Macron is expected to announce plans for sending the trainers when Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky visits France on Thursday for a D-Day commemoration.\n\nThe Biden administration has long {"uri": "2024-05-374377883", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-31", "time": "11:03:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-31T11:03:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-31T10:56:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/nato-chief-dismisses-russian-warnings-after-lifting-of-arms-restrictions/79217059", "title": "NATO chief dismisses Russian warnings after lifting of arms restrictions", "body": "PRAGUE (Reuters) - NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg on Friday dismissed warnings by Russian President Vladimir Putin that allowing Kyiv to use Western weapons for strikes inside Russian territory might lead to an escalation.\n\nSpeaking on the sidelines of a NATO foreign ministers' meeting in Prague, Stoltenberg said the alliance had heard such warnings many times before.\n\n\"This is nothing new. It has ... been the case for a long time that every time NATO allies are providing support to Ukraine, President Putin is trying to threaten us to not do that,\" he told reporters.\n\n\"And an escalation - well, Russia has escalated by invading another country.\"\n\nPutin on Tuesday warned NATO members against allowing Ukraine to fire their weapons into Russia and raised anew a risk of nuclear war after several allies lifted restrictions imposed on the use of weapons donated to Kyiv.\n\nIn a marked policy shift, U.S. President Joe Biden has also authorized Kyiv the limited use of U.S.-supplied weapons inside Russia, four officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said on Thursday.\n\nBiden's decision applies only to targets inside Russia near the border with the Kharkiv region, where an offensive launched by Moscow on May 10 has overrun some villages, they explained. The U.S. is by far the largest arms donor to Kyiv.\n\nKharkiv, Ukraine's second largest city, is 19 miles (30 km) from the border with Russia.\n\nKHARKIV OFFENSIVE\n\nRussian jetfighters flying inside Russia out of reach of Ukrainian air defences have been supporting the offensive by loosing highly precise glide bombs at Ukrainian defence lines and into Kharkiv, where they have caused numerous civilian casualties.\n\nStoltenberg said Ukraine had the right to strike legitimate military targets inside Russia, especially since the borderline and the frontline near Kharkiv were more or less the same, and it was not reasonable to assume Kyiv should not hit back.\n\n\"Ukraine has the right for self-defence, we have the right to help Ukraine uphold the right for self-defence, and that does not make NATO allies a party to the conflict,\" he added. \"That was the case back in February 2022, that was the case last year, that remains the case.\"\n\nIn Berlin on Friday, a German government spokesman said Ukraine could use weapons supplied by Berlin to defend itself against attacks launched from just inside Russia against the Kharkiv border region, in accordance with international law.\n\nIn Prague, Dutch Foreign Minister Hanke Bruins Slot stressed Ukraine's right to self-defence without imposing geographical borders on the use of weapons.\n\nBut other allies such as Italy refuse to go this far, with its foreign minister arguing that his country was banned by the constitution from allowing Kyiv to use donated weapons outside Ukraine.\n\nLithuania's Foreign Minister Gabrielius Landsbergis called on these allies to change their stance since \"the time is coming when it will be determined whether we as an alliance are serious ... about assisting Ukraine to win this war\".\n\n\"I have always been of an opinion that Ukrainians are absolutely capable of defining the targets. I have full confidence that they know and understand what is needed, where the threat comes from,\" Landsbergis told reporters.\n\nHis comments were echoed by his Polish counterpart Radoslaw Sikorski who stressed that Warsaw had never imposed such restrictions.\n\n\"We wish Ukraine victory, we wish them the recovery of all the occupied territories ... Ukraine has the right to defend itself according to the rules of humanitarian law.\"", "source": {"uri": "swissinfo.ch", "dataType": "news", "title": "SWI swissinfo.ch"}, "authors": [], "concepts": "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.malaymail.com/news/world/2024/05/31/nato-allies-support-grows-for-ukrainian-strikes-in-russia/137469", "title": "Nato allies' support grows for Ukrainian strikes in Russia", "body": "KYIV, May 31 -- Support grew among Nato allies today for using Western-donated weapons to strike inside Russian territory, while Nato chief Jens Stoltenberg downplayed Kremlin warnings of an escalation.\n\nGermany said it had given Ukraine permission to fire German-delivered weapons at targets in Russia, a day after US officials said Washington had partially lifted similar restrictions to allow Ukraine to defend its eastern Kharkiv region, which borders Russia.\n\nKyiv has the \"right under international law to defend itself\" against attacks coming from inside Russia, close to the border with Ukraine, German Chancellor Olaf Scholz's spokesman Steffen Hebestreit said.\n\n\"To this end, it can also use the weapons supplied for this purpose... including those supplied by us,\" he said.\n\nWashington had previously resisted allowing Ukraine to use longer-range US weapons to attack Russian territory, fearing it could drag Nato into a direct conflict with Russia.\n\nThe Kremlin accused the West yesterday of \"entering a new round of escalations in tensions\".\n\nBut Nato secretary general Jens Stoltenberg, speaking to reporters at a meeting of alliance foreign ministers in Prague, responded: \"This is part of efforts by President (Vladimir) Putin and Moscow to prevent Nato allies from supporting Ukraine to defend themselves.\"\n\n\"Ukraine has the right for self defence and we have the right to help Ukraine,\" he said.\n\nSome Nato member states are opposed, however.\n\nItalian Foreign Minister Antonio Tajani said that \"for Italy, it is impossible to use our weapons outside of Ukraine\".\n\n\"We are not fighting against Russia. We're defending Ukraine and it is not the same,\" he said.\n\n'Stop the madness'\n\nA US official said yesterday that President Joe Biden \"had recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use US-supplied weapons or counter-fire purposes in the Kharkiv region so Ukraine can hit back against Russian forces that are attacking them or preparing to attack them\".\n\nThe official said that ATACMS missiles, which could hit deeper inside Russia, were still prohibited.\n\nA second US official confirmed the change of policy, which followed weeks of behind-the-scenes discussions between the White House and top US military and State Department officials.\n\nBiden gave the final sign-off in recent days but the decision was kept secret for operational reasons and only became effective yesterday.\n\nThe change in Washington's thinking was attributed by US officials to Russia's daily pounding of Kharkiv, Ukraine's second biggest city.\n\nIn the latest Russian strikes on the city overnight, five people were killed and 23 wounded, including two children, officials said, warning residents could still be trapped under the rubble.\n\n\"The rescue and search operation continues. All services are working at the scene,\" said regional governor Oleg Synegubov.\n\nKharkiv Mayor Igor Terekhov said there had not been \"a single military person, not a single military object\" present.\n\nUkrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has pressed Western allies for more air defence fire power.\n\n\"Our top priorities are to ensure more air defence systems for Ukraine, joint defence industry projects, and weapons for our warriors, as well as global efforts to force Russia to make peace,\" he said on social media during a visit to Sweden today.\n\n\"Only together we can stop the madness from Moscow,\" he told a press conference in Stockholm.\n\n'The advance is underway'\n\nUkraine has intensified strikes on Russian targets in recent months, claiming drone attacks on military and energy infrastructure targets deep inside the country.\n\nRussia's military said on Friday that it had shot down 29 Ukrainian drones overnight that were targeting the port city of Novorossiisk and an oil depot in Temryuk.\n\nThe Temryuk strike sparked a fire, which raged for several hours before being extinguished, and wounded several oil depot workers, Krasnodar Region Governor Venyamin Kondratyev wrote on the Telegram social media channel.\n\nNo injuries were reported in the Novorossiisk strike, local authorities said.\n\nThe increasing intensity of strikes has come as Russian troops have made gradual advances in Ukraine this year after holding off a Ukrainian counter-offensive last year.\n\nRussian Defence Minister Andrei Belousov said Moscow's forces had seized 880 square kilometres of territory so far in 2024.\n\n\"The advance is underway in all tactical directions,\" he said at a meeting of the Russian-led CSTO security alliance in Almaty, according to Russian news U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken had hinted strongly this week that a change in Washington's position was coming.\n\n\"This is a matter of upholding international law -- Ukraine's right to self-defense,\" NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg said. \"Russia has attacked Ukraine, (which) has the right to defend themselves. And that includes also attacking military legitimate targets inside Russia.\"\n\n\"If you look at the battlefield now, Russia is launching attacks on Ukraine's soil from Russian soil with artillery, missiles, and massing troops,\" he said. \"And, of course, it makes it very hard for Ukraine to defend themselves if they are not allowed to use advanced weapons to repel those attacks.\"\n\nUkrainian officials had stepped up calls on the U.S. administration to allow their forces to defend themselves against attacks originating from Russian territory. Kharkiv, Ukraine's second-largest city, is just 20 kilometers (12 miles) from the Russian border.\n\nUkrainian officials, most notably President Volodymyr Zelenskyy, have been increasingly vocal in arguing that the restriction was putting Ukrainian forces in an untenable situation as Russia intensified attacks around Kharkiv.\n\nRussia has been exploiting a lengthy delay in replenishment of U.S. military aid and Western Europe's inadequate military production that has slowed crucial deliveries to the battlefield for Ukraine.\n\nThe alliance is celebrating its 75th anniversary this year and leaders will be meeting in Washington in July to reaffirm their support. Stoltenberg said he expects to be able to announce at the summit that at least two-thirds of members are meeting their commitment to spend 2% of their gross domestic product on defense.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8154077768", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-30", "time": "21:42:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-30T21:42:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-30T21:42:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.aninews.in/news/world/us/biden-authorises-limited-ukrainian-strikes-inside-russia-using-us-weapons20240531030904/", "title": "Biden authorises limited Ukrainian strikes inside Russia using US weapons", "body": "Washington, DC [US], May 31 (ANI): In a significant shift from longstanding policy, President Joe Biden has authorised Ukraine to conduct targeted strikes within Russian territory using American munitions, CNN reported.\n\nThis decision comes amidst escalating tensions as Russian forces make significant advances near Kharkiv, a city in northeastern Ukraine close to the Russian border, according to two US officials briefed on the matter.\n\nUnder the new directive, Ukraine is permitted to retaliate against Russian forces or targets located near Kharkiv using weaponry supplied by the United States.\n\n\"The president recently directed his team to ensure that Ukraine is able to use US-supplied weapons for counterfire purposes in Kharkiv so Ukraine can hit back at Russian forces hitting them or preparing to hit them,\" one official said, according to CNN.\n\nThis policy adjustment, however, is strictly confined to the vicinity of Kharkiv, with no plans to expand the permitted area, the official added. Ukrainian authorities have not sought permission for strikes beyond this region.\n\nThe request for this policy change was made by Kyiv in response to the advancing Russian forces in recent weeks, the official confirmed. Ukrainian forces are now empowered to target Russian military installations, ammunition depots, and logistical hubs across the border from Kharkiv in western Russia.\n\nNevertheless, the Biden administration has maintained its stance against allowing Ukraine to utilize its most formidable munitions, including the long-range ATACMS missiles, which have a range of up to 200 miles (300 kilometers), as reported by CNN.\n\nSecretary of State Antony Blinken hinted at the possibility of adjusting the administration's approach earlier this week. \"Another hallmark of our support for Ukraine over the last two years has been to adapt as the conditions have changed,\" Blinken remarked during a visit to Moldova. \"I am confident we will continue to do that.\"\n\nThe shift in policy aligns with recent statements from European leaders, including French President Emmanuel Macron and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz. Macron emphasised the need for Ukraine to neutralise military sites within Russia that pose a threat to Ukrainian territory. \"Ukrainian soil is being attacked from bases in Russia,\" Macron stated.\n\n\"We think that we should allow them to neutralise the military sites from which the missiles are fired and, basically, the military sites from which Ukraine is attacked.\"\n\nScholz echoed Macron's sentiments, affirming that Ukraine has the right to defend itself within the parameters set by the countries supplying the weapons and international law, CNN reported.
